  • Recognize the morphological characteristics of Strongyloides stercoralis in stool samples and understand its clinical presentation to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment of strongyloidiasis.

choices.text: Oxyhemoglobin
Deoxyhemoglobin
Alkaline hematin
Acid hematin

questions.text: In the assessment of anemia, a clinician uses a traditional device to measure hemoglobin levels. Which type of hemoglobin conversion does this instrument primarily measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acid hematin

 

  • The correct answer, D. Acid hematin, pertains to the use of the Sahli hemometer, a traditional device for measuring hemoglobin levels.
  • This device employs hydrochloric acid to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, a compound that can be easily quantified by comparing its color intensity to a standardized scale.
  • The color transformation reflects the concentration of hemoglobin, allowing for an estimation of hemoglobin levels in the blood, which is crucial for diagnosing and managing anemia.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Oxyhemoglobin: This choice is incorrect because although oxyhemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin bound with oxygen, the Sahli hemometer does not measure this directly. Instead, it chemically alters hemoglobin irrespective of its oxygenation state.
 

Option B. Deoxyhemoglobin: Similar to oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin refers to hemoglobin not bound to oxygen. The Sahli method does not measure this form directly; it involves a chemical alteration that converts any form of hemoglobin to acid hematin.
 

Option C. Alkaline hematin: This option is also incorrect because the Sahli method uses hydrochloric acid, not an alkaline agent, to convert hemoglobin into a measurable form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Sahli hemometer uses hydrochloric acid to convert hemoglobin to acid hematin for the purpose of measuring hemoglobin levels, making it a crucial tool in the diagnosis and management of anemia.
  • This method highlights the chemical transformation of hemoglobin, which is central to the device's functionality.

choices.text: Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
Erythema infectiosum - infants

questions.text: Which of the following pairs incorrectly associates a clinical manifestation of parvovirus with the affected population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women

 

  • Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women is incorrect. Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically a condition affecting older adults, generally over the age of 50, and is not linked to parvovirus infection.
  • This inflammatory disorder features symptoms like muscle pain and stiffness, particularly in the shoulders and hips, which is not a characteristic of parvovirus B19 infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: This is correct. Parvovirus B19 can trigger pure red cell aplasia, especially in individuals with pre-existing conditions like sickle cell disease, where chronic hemolysis is a factor.

 

Option C. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Correct. Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis, a serious condition where abnormal accumulation of fluid occurs in fetal compartments.

 

Option D. Erythema infectiosum - infants: This is correct. Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, predominantly affects children and can present with a "slapped cheek" rash. It is not limited to infants but includes them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that while parvovirus B19 can affect different populations with varying manifestations, it is essential to correctly identify which symptoms align with specific patient groups.
  • This understanding is crucial in diagnosing and managing the effects of parvovirus B19 infection effectively.

choices.text: HSP is most commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection.
The pathology involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and deposition of IgA in the glomerular mesangium.
Hallmark feature of HSP is arthralgia.
Renal involvement can lead to hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a rash, abdominal pain, and joint pain. The child's parents mention that the symptoms began after a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On physical examination, the child has palpable purpura on the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as arthralgia. The physician suspects Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). Which of the following statements about Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hallmark feature of HSP is arthralgia.

 

  • False. The hallmark feature of HSP is palpable purpura, not arthralgia.
  • While arthralgia is common, it is not the hallmark feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSP is most commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection: True. HSP is most commonly seen in children aged 3-8 years and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Option B. The pathology involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and deposition of IgA in the glomerular mesangium: True. The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the glomerular mesangium.

 

Option D. Renal involvement can lead to hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome: True. Renal involvement in HSP can lead to hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hallmark feature of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is palpable purpura, not arthralgia.

choices.text: Baygon
TIK 20
Parathion
Endrin

questions.text: A consultant is reviewing cases of poisoning that have presented to the emergency department. The consultant is tasked with identifying which of the listed poisonings would not be appropriately treated with atropine, a muscarinic antagonist. Which of the following poisonings should atropine NOT be used as an antidote?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endrin

 

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine, such as those seen in organophosphate and carbamate poisoning.
  • It works by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors, thereby alleviating symptoms of excessive cholinergic activity like salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome).
  • Endrin is an organochloride pesticide, primarily causing neurotoxic effects, including seizures.
  • The mechanism of toxicity involves disruption of the central nervous system rather than the cholinergic system.
  • Therefore, atropine is not effective in managing Endrin poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baygon: Atropine is indicated as it counters the acetylcholine accumulation due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition caused by organophosphates/carbamates in Baygon.

 

Option B. TIK 20: As an organophosphate, TIK 20 poisoning results in excessive acetylcholine, where atropine is beneficial.

 

Option C. Parathion: Parathion is an organophosphate pesticide causing acetylcholinesterase inhibition, making atropine an effective treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endrin is an organochloride pesticide. It leads to neurotoxicity, and in that case, Atropine cannot be used in the treatment.
  • Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate and carbamate.
  • For all of these poisonings, atropine is the mainstay of management.

choices.text: PA view in full inspiration
AP view in full inspiration
PA view in full expiration
DAP view in full expiration

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) experiences sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing. Examination reveals no breath sounds on the left side. To best diagnose his condition via chest x-ray, which view should be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PA view in full expiration

 

  • In cases where a pneumothorax is suspected—indicated by sudden onset chest pain, shortness of breath, and absent breath sounds on one side—an expiratory PA view is often more diagnostic than inspiratory views.
  • The expiratory view enhances the visibility of any potential pneumothorax because the lung volume is reduced, making even a small pneumothorax more apparent as there is less air in the lungs to mask its presence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PA view in full inspiration: Incorrect for diagnosing pneumothorax. While PA views in full inspiration are standard for most chest x-rays, they may not as effectively reveal a small pneumothorax compared to an expiratory view.

 

Option B. AP view in full inspiration: Incorrect. AP views are typically used when the patient cannot be positioned properly for a PA view, such as in very ill or bedridden patients. While it can be useful, it is not the optimal choice for diagnosing a pneumothorax as the heart and mediastinum can obscure parts of the lungs.

 

Option D. DAP view in full expiration: Incorrect. The DAP (Dorsal Anterior Posterior) view is not a standard chest x-ray view and does not provide the clarity needed for diagnosing conditions like a pneumothorax compared to PA or AP views.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For diagnosing a suspected pneumothorax, particularly in a case presenting with symptoms like sudden chest pain and shortness of breath with unilateral absent breath sounds, a PA view in full expiration is most effective.

choices.text: Right dorso-anterior
Occipito-posterior
Knee
Brow

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida in active labor experiences a repeated urge to pass urine and premature bearing down. Examination reveals infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart sounds are auscultated on the lateral side. What is the most likely fetal position?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occipito-posterior

 

  • The occipito-posterior (OP) position is when the fetus's head is positioned with the occiput facing the mother's back.
  • This position often results in a more painful and prolonged labor due to the misalignment of the fetal head with the maternal pelvis.
  • Symptoms such as a repeated urge to pass urine, premature bearing down, and infra-umbilical flattening are typical in this position.
  • The fetal heart sounds being heard on the lateral side also suggest this malposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right dorso-anterior: Right dorso-anterior refers to a breech position where the fetal back is facing the mother's anterior side on the right. This position would not typically cause the infra-umbilical flattening or the premature bearing down described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Knee: Knee presentation is very rare and involves the knee being the presenting part. This type of presentation is unlikely to cause the symptoms described.       

                                                                                       

Option D. Brow: Brow presentation occurs when the fetal head is partially extended, with the brow as the presenting part. This would typically present with a high, floating fetal head rather than infra-umbilical flattening and would not produce the urge to bear down prematurely as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The occipito-posterior position in labor is associated with symptoms such as infra-umbilical flattening, premature bearing down, and a repeated urge to pass urine.
  • These signs help identify the fetal malposition, which can complicate labor.

choices.text: Inguinal ligament
Pectineal ligament
Linea semilunaris
Lacunar ligament

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linea semilunaris

 

  • The aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle contributes to the formation of several important anatomical structures. These include:
    • Inguinal ligament: This ligament runs from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle and is formed by the lower border of the external oblique aponeurosis.
    • Pectineal ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, it is an extension of the inguinal ligament along the pectineal line of the pubic bone.
    • Lacunar ligament: This ligament connects the inguinal ligament to the pubic bone, forming the medial border of the femoral canal.
  • The linea semilunaris, however, is a curved tendinous line on the anterior abdominal wall, located at the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle. It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle but rather marks the transition between the muscle and its aponeurosis.

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The linea semilunaris is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle, whereas the inguinal ligament, pectineal ligament, and lacunar ligament are all derived from it.

choices.text: Due to Na+/K+ ATPase pump
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is being evaluated for cardiac function, and their myocardial action potential is studied. Based on the marked point on the action potential curve provided, which statement is true regarding the mechanisms at this point?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

  • The marked point on the myocardial action potential curve corresponds to the plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential.
  • This phase is characterized by a balance between the inward flow of calcium ions through slow (L-type) calcium channels and the outward flow of potassium ions.
  • The slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels maintains the membrane potential in a depolarized state, which is crucial for the contraction of the heart muscle, ensuring a sustained contraction necessary for effective pumping action.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Due to Na+/K+ ATPase pump: The Na+/K+ ATPase pump is primarily involved in maintaining the resting membrane potential and ionic gradients by pumping Na+ out and K+ into the cell. It is not responsible for the plateau phase of the action potential.

 

Option B. Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel: While the closure of fast Na+ channels occurs at the end of the initial depolarization, the opening of slow K+ channels happens later, contributing to repolarization rather than the plateau phase.

 

Option D. Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels: The opening of fast Na+ channels leads to the rapid depolarization (Phase 0) of the action potential, not the plateau phase. The closure of fast K+ channels also occurs early in the action potential process, not during the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The plateau phase (Phase 2) of the myocardial action potential is maintained by the slow but prolonged opening of L-type calcium channels, which allows for a sustained depolarization essential for effective cardiac muscle contraction.

choices.text: Community-acquired pneumonia
Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia (COP)
Acute exacerbation of COPD
Bronchiectasis

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a subacute onset of cough, dyspnea, and low-grade fever for the past 2 months. Physical examination reveals inspiratory crackles. Patient gives history of taking 3 courses of Antibiotics, prior to the current presentation. HRCT of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia (COP)

 

  • COP typically presents in patients over 50 years old with subacute flu-like symptoms, including cough, dyspnea, and fever. Inspiratory crackles are a common finding.
  • The subacute nature of the illness and lack of clear infectious etiology differentiate it from pneumonia.
  • Chest CT findings include patchy, sometimes migratory, subpleural consolidative opacities (as is apparent on this image) often with associated ground-glass opacities.
  • Peribronchiolar or perilobar opacities can be present, and sometimes a rim of subpleural sparing (often referred to as a reversed halo or atoll sign) can be seen, which can help to aid in the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • COP should be considered in older patients presenting with subacute respiratory symptoms, even without a history of smoking or underlying lung disease.

choices.text: Treatment failure of ART
Drug hypersensitivity reaction to ART
Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS)
New opportunistic infection unrelated to HIV

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of HIV infection was recently initiated on antiretroviral therapy (ART). Two weeks later, he presents with fever, cough, and worsening lymphadenopathy. He reports feeling better initially after starting ART, but his symptoms have now returned with greater intensity. He has no known history of opportunistic infections. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his current presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS)

 

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with IRIS, a paradoxical worsening of pre-existing or unmasking of new infections following the initiation of ART.
  • The initial improvement followed by a worsening of symptoms is characteristic of IRIS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment failure of ART: Treatment failure would typically manifest as a lack of improvement or a gradual decline in CD4 count, not a sudden worsening of symptoms.

 

Option B. Drug hypersensitivity reaction to ART: Drug hypersensitivity reactions can cause a variety of symptoms, but the timing and clinical presentation don't align with this patient's case.

 

Option D. New opportunistic infection unrelated to HIV: While possible, the timing of the symptoms suggests a connection to the recent initiation of ART, making IRIS more likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IRIS is a paradoxical inflammatory reaction that can occur after starting ART.
  • Clinicians should be vigilant for signs and symptoms of IRIS in patients with a low CD4 count or high viral load who are starting ART.

choices.text: Gestational diabetes mellitus
Hypertension treated with ACE inhibitors
Pre-gestational diabetes
Effect of valproate

questions.text: A newborn presents with congenital anomalies as depicted in the image. What maternal condition most likely led to these findings in the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

  • Pre-gestational diabetes, especially if poorly controlled, can lead to a variety of congenital anomalies in the fetus.
  • The image shows a neonate with caudal regression syndrome, a condition strongly associated with maternal diabetes.
  • This syndrome includes a spectrum of malformations of the lower spine and extremities, which are characteristic of infants born to mothers with pre-gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gestational diabetes mellitus: While gestational diabetes can lead to macrosomia and neonatal hypoglycemia, it is less commonly associated with major congenital anomalies like caudal regression syndrome seen in this image.

 

Option B. Hypertension treated with ACE inhibitors: Maternal use of ACE inhibitors during pregnancy can cause renal dysgenesis, oligohydramnios, and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but it is not typically associated with the anomalies seen in the image.

 

Option D. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure in utero is associated with neural tube defects, facial dysmorphism, and other anomalies, but it does not typically result in the pattern of malformations seen in the image, which are indicative of caudal regression syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pre-gestational diabetes is strongly associated with caudal regression syndrome and other major congenital anomalies, highlighting the importance of optimal glycemic control before and during pregnancy.

choices.text: Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices
Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient
Surgical options including lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking
All of the above

questions.text: What is the management of Lymphedema praecox syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • Primary lymphedema (like lymphedema praecox) management includes a combination of limb elevation, compression devices, moisturizers, manual lymphatic drainage, and surgical options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices: These methods help reduce swelling in lymphedema.

 

Option B. Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient: Aids in interstitial fluid evacuation.

 

Option C. Surgical options including lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking: Employed in severe cases to manage lymphedema effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema praecox syndrome requires a comprehensive management approach including non-surgical and surgical options to effectively control symptoms and prevent complications.

choices.text: Oral stage
Anal stage
Phallic stage
Latency stage

questions.text: During a well-child visit, a mother expresses concern about her 4-year-old son's behaviour. She reports that he has become very interested in his genitals and often touches them in public. He has also started asking questions about where babies come from and why boys and girls look different. According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which stage is this child likely in?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Phallic stage

 

  • The child's behavior and interests described in this vignette are characteristic of the phallic stage in Freud's theory of psychosexual development.
  • This stage typically occurs between the ages of 3 and 6 years. During this stage, the child's libido is focused on the genitals, and the child becomes aware of anatomical sex differences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral stage: This occurs from birth to about 1 year and focuses on oral gratification.

 

Option B. Anal stage: This occurs from about 1 to 3 years and focuses on toilet training and control.

 

Option D. Latency stage: This occurs from about 6 years to puberty and is characterized by a decrease in sexual interest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The phallic stage in Freud's psychosexual theory occurs between ages 3-6 years, characterized by focus on the genitals and the development of the Oedipus complex.

choices.text: Primary tuberculosis
Secondary (Reactivation) tuberculosis
Miliary tuberculosis
Latent tuberculosis

questions.text: A pathology specimen from a 42-year-old patient presenting with productive cough, fever, and night sweats shows lung tissue with the characteristics displayed in the image. Which type of tuberculosis does this specimen most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary tuberculosis

 

  • The correct answer is A, Primary tuberculosis. On closer inspection, caseous tan necrotic tissue is seen to constitute the granulomas in this gross appearance of a Ghon complex, which is a classical finding in primary tuberculosis.
  • A Ghon's complex consists of a Ghon focus, representing a primary lung lesion, and involvement of the regional lymph nodes.
  • This is characteristic of primary tuberculosis, where the initial infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis leads to these localized lesions in the lung, often with no symptoms or only mild symptoms.

 

Other Options:


 

Option B. Secondary (Reactivation) tuberculosis: Typically involves the reactivation of previously dormant lesions, commonly in the apex of the lung, and does not typically feature a Ghon's complex.


 

Option C. Miliary tuberculosis: Characterized by the widespread dissemination of numerous tiny lesions throughout the lung and other organs, not the localized involvement seen in the image.


 

Option D. Latent tuberculosis: There are no physical manifestations in the lung tissues as the infection is contained and inactive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary tuberculosis is associated with the formation of a Ghon's complex, which is a combination of a lung lesion and lymph node involvement, characteristic of an initial infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

choices.text: Auditory area
Motor speech area
Visual area
Wernicke's area

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a vascular injury affecting the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be impacted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Motor speech area

 

  • The inferior frontal gyrus is part of the frontal lobe of the brain and includes Broca's area, which is the motor speech area.
  • Broca's area is responsible for language production and articulation.
  • Damage to this area can result in Broca's aphasia, characterized by difficulties in speech production while comprehension generally remains intact.
  • This area is crucial for the motor aspects of speech, such as forming words and constructing sentences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory area: The auditory area, also known as the primary auditory cortex, is located in the temporal lobe. It is responsible for processing auditory information and is not located in the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

Option C. Visual area: The visual area, also known as the primary visual cortex, is located in the occipital lobe. It is responsible for processing visual information and is not affected by damage to the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

Option D. Wernicke's area: Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension and is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus. It is not located in the inferior frontal gyrus, so damage to this area does not affect Wernicke's area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The motor speech area, or Broca's area, is located in the inferior frontal gyrus and is responsible for language production and articulation.
  • Damage to this area can lead to Broca's aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production.

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
CA 19-9
CA 125

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B infection presents with a new liver mass. Which tumor marker is most useful for the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 

  • AFP is a protein produced by the fetal liver and yolk sac.
  • It is considered the most useful tumor marker for HCC, although it can also be elevated in other conditions like pregnancy and chronic liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): CEA is primarily associated with colorectal cancer.

 

Option C. CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is associated with pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D. CA 125: CA 125 is associated with ovarian cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • AFP is the most specific tumor marker for HCC, but it is not always elevated in all cases of HCC.

choices.text: Neer classification grade 4
Ideberg classification grade 4
Garden classification grade 3
Schatzker classification grade 5

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neer classification grade 4

 

Type of fracture: Neer classification categorizes proximal humerus fractures based on the number of fragments and the involvement of the surgical neck of the humerus.

 

Grade 4: This type of fracture includes fractures that involve the surgical neck of the humerus with displacement, often resulting in multiple fragments.

 

Characteristics: Grade 4 fractures typically involve severe displacement and comminution (multiple fragments) of the proximal humerus, which can complicate treatment and may require surgical intervention for stabilization.

 

Clinical significance: These fractures are challenging due to the disruption of blood supply to the humeral head, which can lead to avascular necrosis if not managed appropriately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4:

 

  • Type of classification: Ideberg classification is used specifically for calcaneus (heel bone) fractures and not for shoulder fractures. Therefore, this option is incorrect in the context of a shoulder X-ray.

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3:

 

  •   Type of classification: Garden classification is used for femoral neck fractures and is not applicable to shoulder fractures. Grade 3 in Garden classification typically refers to a complete fracture with partial displacement.

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5:

 

  •   Type of classification: Schatzker classification is primarily used for tibial plateau fractures and is not used for shoulder fractures. Grade 5 in Schatzker classification typically refers to a bicondylar fracture of the tibial plateau.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neer classification grade, this classification specifically describes proximal humerus fractures involving the surgical neck with severe displacement and comminution.

choices.text: Interstitial cystitis
Malakoplakia
Polypoid cystitis
Acute cystitis

questions.text: A 43-year old patient underwent cystoscopy, which revealed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is provided. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

  • Malakoplakia is characterized by the presence of yellow-white plaques in the bladder mucosa, often in the trigone area.
  • Histologically, it features large histiocytes (von Hansemann cells) with basophilic inclusions called Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are pathognomonic for this condition.
  • These inclusions are due to defective phagocytosis of bacteria, typically Escherichia coli, leading to a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis, also known as painful bladder syndrome, typically presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and frequency. Cystoscopic findings may include glomerulations (pinpoint hemorrhages) but not yellow-white plaques. Histologically, it shows inflammatory infiltrates, mast cells, and fibrosis.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis is a reactive inflammatory condition of the bladder often associated with chronic irritation, such as from indwelling catheters. It is characterized by the presence of polypoid projections of the mucosa but does not present with yellow-white plaques or the histological features seen in malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis presents with symptoms of urinary tract infection, such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. Cystoscopic findings typically show erythematous and edematous mucosa with petechial hemorrhages. Histologically, it is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration but lacks the hallmark features of malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malakoplakia is identified by the presence of yellow-white plaques in the bladder and histologically by the presence of von Hansemann cells and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, indicative of a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response to bacterial infection.

choices.text: Keloid refers to excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site.
Keloid shows growth of the scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound.
Keloid is often glossy in appearance and rubbery in texture.
Keloid shows regression after a few years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding keloid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Keloid shows regression after a few years.

 

  • Keloids are a type of scar that result from an overproduction of collagen at the site of skin injury.
  • They extend beyond the original boundaries of the wound and do not regress over time.
  • The appearance of keloids is typically glossy and they have a rubbery texture.
  • These scars are often persistent and can even grow larger with time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keloid refers to excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site: This is true as keloids are characterized by an excessive buildup of collagen.

 

Option B. Keloid shows growth of the scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound: This is true because keloids expand beyond the initial area of injury.

 

Option C. Keloid is often glossy in appearance and rubbery in texture: This is true as keloids typically have a glossy, shiny surface and feel rubbery to the touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Keloids do not regress over time; they persist and can continue to grow beyond the original wound boundaries.

choices.text: Adulteration of food
Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters
Regulating labor in mines
Public health and sanitation

questions.text: Which of the following items is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adulteration of food

 

  • Adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List in India, which means both the central and state governments have the authority to legislate on this matter.
  • The legislative division in the seventh schedule of the Indian Constitution comprises three distinct lists:

 

  1. The Union List: Encompassing 100 items over which the parliament holds exclusive legislative authority.
  2. The State List: Containing 61 items subject to the exclusive legislative jurisdiction of state governments.
  3. The Concurrent List: Consisting of 52 items wherein both the central and state governments possess the authority to legislate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This item is included in the Union List.

 

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This item is included in the Union List.

 

Option D. Public health and sanitation: This item is included in the State List.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Concurrent list under Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare includes: [responsibility of both Union and State governments]
  •  [Mnemonic: V CLAPPED]
    • Vital statistics
    • Communicable diseases spread prevention
    • Labour welfare
    • Adulteration of food prevention
    • Ports other than major
    • Population control and family planning
    • Economic and social planning
    • Drugs and poisons control

choices.text: VIII
IV
III and IV
III, VI, and VIII

questions.text: In the neurological evaluation of an unresponsive patient, the oculocephalic reflex, often referred to as "doll's eye," is tested to assess the brainstem's function. This reflex involves the rapid turning of the head to one side and observing the eyes' response. Which cranial nerve is NOT evaluated through the oculocephalic reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV 

 

  • The oculocephalic reflex evaluates the integrity of the oculomotor (III), abducens (VI), and, indirectly, the vestibular functions of VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve), which can influence eye movements through vestibulo-ocular connections.
  • The trochlear nerve (IV), which innervates the superior oblique muscle, is not specifically assessed by this reflex.
  • The oculocephalic reflex primarily checks the ability of the eyes to move conjugately to the opposite side of head rotation, a function predominantly involving the lateral and medial rectus muscles, controlled by cranial nerves VI and III, respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIII : The vestibulocochlear nerve is indirectly involved in the oculocephalic reflex through vestibulo-ocular reflex pathways.

 

Option C. III and IV: Cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve) is indeed assessed during this reflex.

 

Option D. III, VI, and VIII: Cranial nerves III (oculomotor) and VI (abducens) are directly evaluated, and VIII (vestibulocochlear) is indirectly involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The oculocephalic reflex primarily assesses the lateral and medial rectus muscles, governed by cranial nerves VI and III, respectively, and does not assess the function of the superior oblique muscle, controlled by cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve).
  • Understanding which cranial nerves are evaluated through specific reflexes is critical in neurological examinations.

choices.text: West Bengal
UP
Bihar
Assam

questions.text: An epidemiologist is mapping out regions in India where Kala-azar is endemic to target interventions. According to the data, which of the following states is not endemic for Kala-azar?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assam

 

  • Kala-azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania donovani parasite and transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies (Phlebotomus).
  • The states where Kala-azar is endemic include:
  • Uttar Pradesh (UP)
  • West Bengal (WB)
  • Bihar
  • Jharkhand

 

Assam is not listed among the states endemic for Kala-azar.

 

Educational objective:

choices.text: Haptocorrin
Ferroportin
Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1)
Divalent metal transporter 2

questions.text: Which transporter is primarily responsible for the uptake of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1)

 

  • The correct answer is C, Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). DMT1 is essential for the transportation of divalent metal ions, including iron, into enterocytes in the duodenum.
  • It specifically transports ferrous iron (Fe2+) from the intestinal lumen into the cells, playing a crucial role in iron absorption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haptocorrin: This is a cobalamin-binding protein involved in the protection and transport of vitamin B12 in the digestive tract, not iron.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: Ferroportin is involved in exporting iron from cells, including enterocytes, into the bloodstream, rather than importing it into cells.

 

Option D. Divalent metal transporter 2: This is a less commonly referenced transporter in literature and is not specifically known for its role in iron transport into enterocytes like DMT1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DMT1 is critical for the absorption of iron into enterocytes by transporting ferrous iron (Fe2+) from the intestinal lumen into the cells, a fundamental step in the body's iron uptake process.

choices.text: Park’s index
Smith’s index
Sullivan’s index
Life index

questions.text: An epidemiologist is analyzing different indices used to measure life expectancy and quality of life for a comprehensive health study. She wants to determine which index specifically measures the expectation of life free of disability. What is this index known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sullivan’s index

 

  • Sullivan’s Index = Life Expectancy minus Duration of disability (bed disability and inability to perform major activities)
  • It is one of the most advanced indicators currently available
  • Is known as ‘Disability free life expectancy (DFLE)

 

Other Options:

 

Other 3 options are not related to life expectancy or disability-free life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The simplest index of health which incorporates morbidity as well as mortality is Sullivan’s Index of Disability-Free Life Expectancy (DFLE).

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: A corporate compliance officer is conducting a workshop on labor laws to ensure the company's manufacturing unit adheres to legal standards. She poses the following question to the participants. Which of the following statements accurately describes the Factories Act?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories

 

  • Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories: This is correct according to the Factories Act, which prohibits the employment of children under the age of 14 in any factory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM: This is incorrect. The Factories Act states that children between 14-18 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 7 PM.

 

Option C. The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week: This is incorrect. The Factories Act specifies that the maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day. With overtime included, it should not exceed 60 hours per week.

 

Option D. A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day: This is incorrect. Children between 14-18 years should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factories Act, 1948

 

  • Scope: The Act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more persons where power is used and 20 or more persons where power is not used
  • Work related norms:
    • Employment of young persons.
    • Employment prohibited for age less than 14 years.
    • 15-18 years old adolescents to be declared fit by ‘certifying surgeons’; will work only between 6AM to 7PM.
    • Employment prohibited in certain dangerous occupations.
    • Hours of work:
      • A maximum of 4½ hours of work per day for adolescents.
      • 48 hours per week (9 hrs per day).
      • Maximum 60 hours per week (including overtime).
    • Leave with wages:
      • 1 day per 15 days of work for adolescents
      • Leaves can be accumulated up to 40 days
    • Health, Safety and Welfare recommendations:
      • A minimum of 500 cubic feet space per worker
      • 1 Safety Officer per 1000 workers
      • 1 Welfare Officer per 500 workers
      • 1 Canteen for greater than 250 workers
      • 1 Crèche for greater than 30 women workers
    • Under Factories Act 1948, there are 29 diseases which are notifiable (Schedule 3): Silicosis, Anthracosis, Byssinosis and Asbestosis

choices.text: Effect to cause design
Used to study rare diseases
Odds ratio can be calculated
Cause to effect design

questions.text: A public health researcher is designing a study to investigate potential risk factors for a rare neurological disorder. She is considering using a case-control study design. Which of the following statements is not true about case-control studies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cause to effect design

 

  • A case-control study is a retrospective study that starts with the outcome (disease) and looks backward in time to investigate potential exposures or risk factors that may have contributed to the disease.
  • This is known as an "effect to cause" design, as it begins with the effect (disease) and seeks to identify causes (exposures).

 

Other Options:

 

Key points about case-control studies:

 

Option A. Effect to cause design: True. Case-control studies start with cases (individuals with the disease) and controls (individuals without the disease), then look back in time to assess exposure.

 

Option B. Used to study rare diseases: True. Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases because they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort.

 

Option C. Odds ratio can be calculated: True. The strength of the association between exposure and outcome in case-control studies is measured using the odds ratio, which is calculated using the formula:

 

2 × 2 table

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Case-control studies are retrospective and start with the outcome (disease) to look back at exposures, making them an "effect to cause" design.
  • They are particularly useful for studying rare diseases and use the odds ratio to measure the association between exposure and outcome.

choices.text: Appendectomy
Cholecystectomy
Tonsillectomy
Herniorrhaphy

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries uses the instrument given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tonsillectomy

 

  • The Eves Tonsillar Snare is a specialized surgical instrument used primarily in tonsillectomy procedures.
  • It is designed to excise the tonsils by capturing the tissue in a loop and then cutting it off.
  • This instrument helps in achieving a clean and efficient removal of the tonsils with minimal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appendectomy: Incorrect. Appendectomy, which involves the removal of the appendix, does not use the Eves Tonsillar Snare.

 

Option B. Cholecystectomy: Incorrect. Cholecystectomy, which involves the removal of the gallbladder, does not use the Eves Tonsillar Snare.

 

Option D. Herniorrhaphy: Incorrect. Herniorrhaphy, which involves the repair of a hernia, does not use the Eves Tonsillar Snare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Eves Tonsillar Snare is specifically designed for use in tonsillectomy surgeries, facilitating the removal of tonsils with precision and efficiency.

choices.text: Lewy bodies
Neurofibrillary tangles
Spongiform changes
Oligodendroglial inclusions

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss, disorientation, and difficulty managing his daily activities. His family notes a decline in his cognitive function over the past two years, which has worsened in recent months. A neurologic examination reveals impaired short-term memory and apraxia. An MRI shows diffuse cortical atrophy. A definitive diagnosis would most likely be confirmed by finding which of the following on histopathological examination of the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurofibrillary tangles

 

  • The correct answer is B, Neurofibrillary tangles. This patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by progressive cognitive decline, memory impairment, and functional deterioration.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles, composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein, are a hallmark histopathological finding in Alzheimers disease, along with amyloid plaques.
  • These tangles contribute to the disruption of neuronal transport systems, leading to cell death and the symptoms observed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lewy bodies: Found in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, these are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions, primarily made of alpha-synuclein. The clinical presentation of fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism would be more indicative of Lewy body dementia.

 

 

Option C. Spongiform changes: These are characteristic of prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which typically presents with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and sometimes a characteristic MRI finding, but the progression is much faster than that seen in this patient.

 

 

Option D. Oligodendroglial inclusions: These are seen in multiple system atrophy, another neurodegenerative disease, and would not typically present with the cognitive and memory impairments described in the scenario but rather with autonomic dysfunction and movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurofibrillary tangles are a key pathological feature of Alzheimers disease and directly correlate with the degree of dementia, particularly in the context of a clinical presentation involving progressive cognitive decline and brain atrophy on imaging.

 

Pathophysiology Summary:

 

  1. Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is abnormally cleaved A42 peptide plaques
  2. Tau protein, a microtubule-associated protein, becomes hyperphosphorylated tangles
  3. These lead to neuronal dysfunction and death, especially in the hippocampus and association cortices.

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: After fitting a pessary, what is the first step to check if it is adequately retained?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

  • The first step after fitting a pessary to check if it is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver.
  • This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure and can help determine whether the pessary remains in place under conditions that mimic the increased pressure that occurs during activities such as coughing, sneezing, or lifting.
  • If the pessary is dislodged or moves significantly during this maneuver, it indicates that it may not be the correct size or is not adequately retained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: While it is important to ensure the patient can void comfortably with the pessary in place, this step is typically performed after confirming retention with the Valsalva maneuver. Voiding does not significantly test the retention of the pessary under increased intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option C. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Patient discomfort can indicate an improperly fitted pessary, but the absence of discomfort alone does not confirm adequate retention. The Valsalva maneuver is a more definitive test for retention.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This option is incorrect as it does not pertain to the correct method of checking pessary retention. Proper fitting involves ensuring the pessary is snug but not overly tight, and being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary is not a recognized method of checking retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Valsalva maneuver is used to test the retention of a pessary after fitting, ensuring it remains in place under increased intra-abdominal pressure.

choices.text: Spina bifida occulta
Meningocele
Myelomeningocele
Anencephaly

questions.text: A newborn presents with a sac-like protrusion in the lumbar region. Based on the image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myelomeningocele

 

  • The image and description are indicative of myelomeningocele, a type of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meningeal coverings protrude through a vertebral defect.
  • This condition often leads to significant neurological impairment due to the exposure and potential damage to the spinal cord and nerves.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spina bifida occulta: Incorrect. Spina bifida occulta is the mildest form of spina bifida where the vertebral defect is present but there is no protrusion of the meninges or spinal cord.

 

Option B. Meningocele: Incorrect. Meningocele involves the protrusion of the meninges through a vertebral defect, but the spinal cord remains in place.

 

Option D. Anencephaly: Incorrect. Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myelomeningocele is characterized by the protrusion of the spinal cord and meningeal coverings through a vertebral defect, leading to significant neurological impairment.

choices.text: O2 @ 3L/min
CO2 @ 3L/min
O2 @ 12L/min
CO2 @ 12L/min

questions.text: What is the maximum flow of gas permissible from the device shown in laparoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CO2 @ 3L/min

 

  • The device shown in the image is a Veress needle, which is used to create pneumoperitoneum during laparoscopic procedures.
  • The maximum flow rate of CO2 through a Veress needle is typically set at 3 liters per minute to safely and effectively insufflate the abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 @ 3L/min: Oxygen is not used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic procedures because it poses a risk of combustion.

 

Option C. O2 @ 12L/min: Similarly, a high flow rate of oxygen is not used due to the risk of fire and combustion in the presence of electrocautery.

 

Option D. CO2 @ 12L/min: A flow rate of 12 liters per minute is too high for safe insufflation during laparoscopic procedures and could lead to complications such as gas embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Veress needle is used to safely create pneumoperitoneum by insufflating CO2 into the abdominal cavity at a controlled flow rate, typically not exceeding 3 liters per minute, to avoid complications and ensure the effectiveness of the laparoscopic procedure.

choices.text: Acyclovir and induction of labor
Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery
Spontaneous delivery
Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents at 36 weeks of gestation with painful vulval ulcers. She reports no history of similar lesions. On examination, multiple painful vesicular lesions are observed. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

  • The presence of multiple painful vesicular lesions at 36 weeks of gestation is indicative of a primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
  • Primary HSV infection during pregnancy, particularly close to delivery, poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can be severe.
  • The best management in this situation includes antiviral treatment with acyclovir to manage the maternal infection and an elective Cesarean section to prevent neonatal exposure to the virus during vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir and induction of labor: Induction of labor is not appropriate in this scenario as it increases the risk of neonatal HSV transmission during vaginal delivery.

 

Option B. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Although antiviral therapy is part of the treatment, normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Allowing spontaneous vaginal delivery is not appropriate in the presence of active genital HSV lesions due to the high risk of neonatal transmission and subsequent severe infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a pregnant woman presenting with active HSV lesions at 36 weeks gestation, the appropriate management includes antiviral therapy with acyclovir and an elective Cesarean section to prevent neonatal herpes transmission.

choices.text: Pseudocyesis
Endometrial hyperplasia
Uterine polyposis
Pyometra

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease presents with severe lower abdominal pain and fever. What condition is likely to result from long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyometra

 

  • Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can lead to pyometra, which is an accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity.
  • PID is caused by bacterial infection, often sexually transmitted, leading to inflammation and scarring of the reproductive organs.
  • Chronic PID can cause obstruction of the cervical canal, resulting in the accumulation of pus in the uterus, which is a serious condition that requires immediate medical intervention to prevent complications such as sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudocyesis: Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and shows symptoms of pregnancy without an actual fetus. It is unrelated to the infectious and inflammatory process of long-standing PID.

 

Option B. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia is characterized by the thickening of the uterine lining due to prolonged estrogen stimulation without progesterone. It is generally associated with hormonal imbalances, not chronic infection or inflammation like PID.

 

Option C. Uterine polyposis: Uterine polyposis involves the presence of benign growths (polyps) in the uterine lining, which are usually related to hormonal factors rather than infections or inflammation from PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease can result in pyometra, which is an accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity due to chronic inflammation and obstruction of the cervical canal.

choices.text: Tamsulosin
Sildenafil
Finasteride
Flutamide

questions.text: A 58-year-old man visits his primary care physician complaining of urinary hesitancy and a decreased stream. After a clinical evaluation, he is diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The physician considers a medication that can directly reduce the size of the prostate over time to alleviate his symptoms. Which of the following drugs is known to decrease the size of the prostate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Finasteride

 

  • It inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its active form, DHT (dihydrotestosterone), by acting as a competitive inhibitor of the 5-reductase enzyme.
  • It has a long-term effect of reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation, which reduces the size of the prostate and improves urine flow.
  • Tamsulosin is a Selective α1A Antagonist which dilates prostatic urethra and hence produces immediate symptom relief in BPH. It has no effect on reducing size of the prostate.
  • Flutamide is an Androgen Receptor antagonist with no hormonal activity. It is used for the treatment of metastatic prostatic cancer in conjunction with GnRH agonists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist. It works by relaxing the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate. While it provides symptomatic relief for BPH, it does not reduce the size of the prostate.

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It has no effect on prostate size.

 

Option D. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. It does not reduce the size of the prostate but works by blocking the effects of androgens (male hormones).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Finasteride decreases the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), thereby reducing prostatic cell proliferation and improving urinary symptoms in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

choices.text: Vagus nerve
Trochlear nerve
Glossopharyngeal nerve
Facial nerve

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with a neurological condition affecting various cranial nerve nuclei. Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear nerve

 

  • The special visceral afferent (SVA) column includes cranial nerve nuclei that are involved in the sensation of taste and smell.
  • These include the facial nerve (VII), glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), and vagus nerve (X).
  • The facial nerve carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, the glossopharyngeal nerve from the posterior one-third of the tongue, and the vagus nerve from the epiglottis and pharynx.
  • The trochlear nerve (IV), however, is not part of the SVA column. It is a motor nerve responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is involved in downward and lateral eye movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (X) is part of the SVA column as it carries taste sensations from the epiglottis and pharynx.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) is part of the SVA column and carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (VII) is part of the SVA column and carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trochlear nerve (IV) is not part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column, which includes cranial nerves involved in taste and smell, such as the facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves.
  • The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve responsible for eye movements.

choices.text: Left cerebellar hemisphere
Left motor cortex
Right basal ganglia
Right cerebellar hemisphere

questions.text: A 53-year-old man c/o 3-month of unsteady gait with a tendency to lean to his right side and a right-hand clumsiness and tremor. Which of the following locations in the patient’s brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right cerebellar hemisphere

 

  • The cerebellum is responsible for the coordination of movement on the ipsilateral side of the body.
  • A lesion of a cerebellar hemisphere would result in ataxia, instability, and dysmetria on the same side of the body as the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left cerebellar hemisphere: A left cerebellar hemisphere lesion would lead to left-sided motor deficits, not right-sided.

 

Option B. Left motor cortex: A lesion of the left motor cortex or the right motor cortex would result in contralateral paralysis.

 

Option C. Right basal ganglia: Damage to the left basal ganglia or right basal ganglia would produce minor motor problems in the contralateral limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cerebellum plays a critical role in coordinating movement and balance. Lesions within the cerebellum manifest with ipsilateral (same-sided) motor deficits.
  • Recognizing these patterns is crucial for accurate localization and diagnosis of neurological conditions.

choices.text: Increase the dose of olanzapine
Add lithium as an adjunct therapy
Start clozapine
Begin a course of electroconvulsive therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a 5-year history of schizophrenia has been treated with risperidone for 2 years and olanzapine for 1 year, with minimal improvement in her positive symptoms. She continues to experience auditory hallucinations and paranoid delusions that significantly impair her daily functioning. What would be the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start clozapine

 

  • This case presents a patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia, defined as failure to respond to at least two adequate trials of different antipsychotic medications.
  • In such cases, clozapine is considered the gold standard treatment.
  • Clozapine has shown superior efficacy in managing treatment-resistant schizophrenia compared to other antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of olanzapine: This might be considered before declaring treatment resistance, but not after two failed trials.

 

Option B. Add lithium as an adjunct therapy: This is not typically the next step for treatment-resistant schizophrenia unless there are prominent mood symptoms.

 

Option D. Begin a course of electroconvulsive therapy: While ECT can be effective in some cases, it's usually considered after a trial of clozapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clozapine is the treatment of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, defined as failure to respond to at least two adequate trials of different antipsychotic medications.

choices.text: Temporalis
Masseter
Medial pterygoid
Lateral pterygoid

questions.text: A 25-year-old student experienced his jaw locking while yawning. Which muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral pterygoid

 

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle of mastication that attaches directly to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).
  • This muscle plays a crucial role in movements of the jaw, such as opening the mouth (depression of the mandible) and protrusion of the jaw.
  • Its attachment to the articular disc helps to stabilize and guide the movements of the TMJ.
  • Dysfunction or spasm of the lateral pterygoid can lead to issues such as jaw locking, especially during wide opening movements like yawning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle is a powerful muscle of mastication that primarily elevates the mandible (closes the mouth). It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option B. Masseter: The masseter muscle is another major muscle of mastication involved in elevating the mandible (closing the mouth). It attaches to the mandible but not to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle assists in elevating the mandible and moving it side-to-side. It also does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral pterygoid muscle attaches to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint and plays a significant role in the movement and function of the TMJ. Its involvement is crucial in conditions leading to jaw locking.

choices.text: Stroke volume and end diastolic volume
End systolic volume and total peripheral resistance
End diastolic volume and pulse pressure
Stroke volume and total peripheral resistance

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is undergoing an evaluation of their cardiac function. Which two parameters of the cardiac cycle are related by the Frank-Starling curve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stroke volume and end diastolic volume

 

  • The Frank-Starling curve illustrates the relationship between stroke volume (the amount of blood ejected by the left ventricle during systole) and end diastolic volume (the volume of blood in the left ventricle at the end of diastole, just before contraction).
  • According to the Frank-Starling law of the heart, the stroke volume increases in response to an increase in end diastolic volume.
  • This mechanism ensures that the heart can adjust its pumping function to match the venous return, thereby maintaining efficient circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. End systolic volume and total peripheral resistance: These parameters are not directly related by the Frank-Starling curve. End systolic volume is influenced by factors like contractility and afterload, while total peripheral resistance affects afterload but is not depicted on the Frank-Starling curve.

 

Option C. End diastolic volume and pulse pressure: Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure and is not directly related to end diastolic volume. The Frank-Starling curve does not illustrate this relationship.

 

Option D. Stroke volume and total peripheral resistance: While total peripheral resistance can influence stroke volume by affecting afterload, the Frank-Starling curve specifically relates stroke volume to end diastolic volume, not total peripheral resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Frank-Starling curve describes the relationship between stroke volume and end diastolic volume, illustrating how the heart adjusts its force of contraction in response to changes in venous return to maintain efficient cardiac output.

choices.text: Trihexyphenidyl
Entacapone
Rasagiline
Pramipexole

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with chronic psychiatric illness has been treated with a high-potency antipsychotic for several months. Recently, he presented with symptoms suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism, including increased muscle rigidity and a noticeable tremor. To counteract these side effects without compromising his mental health treatment, which adjunct medication should be considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trihexyphenidyl

 

  • Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms like Parkinsonism that may arise as a side effect of antipsychotic medications.
  • It can counteract the dopamine antagonism caused by antipsychotic drugs, thereby alleviating symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entacapone: Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease to prolong the action of levodopa. It's not typically used to treat drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Option C. Rasagiline: Rasagiline is a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor used primarily in Parkinson's disease. It's not commonly used for drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Pramipexole: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist also used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but is ineffective in treatment of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotic medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trihexyphenidyl is the appropriate medication for managing extrapyramidal side effects, such as Parkinsonism, induced by antipsychotic medications.
  • It works by counteracting the dopamine antagonism and restoring the balance between acetylcholine and dopamine in the brain.

choices.text: CO2
70% dextrose
Normal saline
Glycine

questions.text: A patient is scheduled to undergo a hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. Which agent should be used for uterine distention?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal saline

 

  • Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery.
  • It is an isotonic solution that does not conduct electricity, which makes it safe and effective for use with bipolar electrocautery instruments.
  • This ensures clear visualization and minimizes the risk of electrolyte imbalances or fluid overload.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2: CO2 is used for distention in some endoscopic procedures but is not suitable for hysteroscopy, particularly when using electrocautery, due to poor visualization and the risk of gas embolism.

 

Option B. 70% dextrose: 70% dextrose is not used as a distention medium in hysteroscopy. It does not provide the necessary clear visualization and poses a risk of significant metabolic complications if absorbed.

 

Option D. Glycine: Glycine is a non-conductive distention medium that is used with monopolar electrocautery, but it is not suitable for bipolar electrocautery because it can lead to electrolyte imbalances and hyponatremia when absorbed in large quantities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Normal saline is the preferred distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its safety, effectiveness, and compatibility with the equipment.

choices.text: Ubiquitin
Mannose 6 Phosphate
Chaperone
Translocon

questions.text: In the context of protein synthesis and trafficking within a cell, which component is primarily responsible for directing proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to their cellular destinations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mannose 6 Phosphate

 

  • Mannose 6 Phosphate is a key signaling molecule used in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) for targeting and transducing proteins to lysosomes.
  • It acts as a tag that binds specific receptors that direct the protein to the lysosome, an essential process for the proper sorting and function of lysosomal enzymes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ubiquitin: Ubiquitin tags proteins for degradation, typically by the proteasome, rather than directing them to lysosomes or other cellular destinations directly from the ER.

 

Option C. Chaperone: Chaperones assist in protein folding and the maintenance of proper protein conformation, but do not themselves direct proteins to specific cellular locations.

 

Option D. Translocon: The translocon is involved in the process of protein translocation across the ER membrane during synthesis but does not direct proteins to specific destinations like lysosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mannose 6 Phosphate plays a critical role in the targeting of lysosomal proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum, guiding them to their correct destination within the cell, which is crucial for cellular metabolism and waste processing.

choices.text: Rickets
Night blindness
Beri-beri
Scurvy

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is known to impair the maturation of collagen, thereby affecting wound healing and connective tissue integrity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scurvy

 

  • Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis.
  • This hydroxylation step is crucial as it provides collagen with the necessary tensile strength by allowing the formation of stable collagen triple helices.
  • Without adequate vitamin C, collagen fibers cannot properly form cross-links, resulting in weakened connective tissue and impaired wound healing.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Rickets: Rickets is caused by a deficiency of vitamin D and affects bone development through impaired calcium and phosphate metabolism, not directly affecting collagen maturation.
 

Option B. Night blindness: Night blindness results from a deficiency of vitamin A, which is critical for the synthesis of the photoreceptor pigments in the eye, unrelated to collagen synthesis or maturation.
 

Option C. Beri-beri: Beri-beri results from a deficiency of vitamin B1 (thiamine) and primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not collagen maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin C is vital for the proper synthesis and maturation of collagen by enabling the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in the collagen structure.
  • A deficiency in vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by weakened connective tissues and impaired wound healing.

choices.text: Maintenance of normal body weight
Preservation of lifestyle
Primitive nutritional habits
Screening for hypertension

questions.text: A Public health specialist is focusing on the different levels of prevention in myocardial infarction (MI) for a community health program. She wants to identify which of the following is not an example of primordial prevention in the context of myocardial infarction. Which is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Screening for hypertension

 

  • Screening for hypertension falls under secondary prevention, as it involves early detection and management of existing risk factors to prevent progression to disease.
  • Primordial prevention aims to prevent the emergence of risk factors in a population by modifying social and environmental determinants.
  • It involves strategies to avoid the development of risk factors in the first place, particularly by promoting healthy lifestyles and environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maintenance of normal body weight: Encouraging healthy weight maintenance is a key aspect of primordial prevention.

 

Option B. Preservation of lifestyle: This refers to maintaining healthy habits and routines that reduce the risk of developing risk factors for myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Primitive nutritional habits: Promoting healthy, balanced diets from an early age to prevent the development of risk factors fits within primordial prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levels of Prevention

choices.text: Therapeutic assessment
Physical assessment
Biochemical assessment
Behavioral assessment

questions.text: A public health professional is preparing a training session on the WHO's STEP approach for chronic disease risk factor surveillance. Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • Therapeutic assessment is not part of the STEPS approach.

 

Other Options:

 

The WHO's STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method designed for chronic disease risk factor surveillance. It includes the following steps:

 

Option B. Physical assessment: This includes measurements of height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure. Expanded measurements may include hip circumference and heart rate.

 

Option C. Biochemical assessment: This involves measuring blood glucose and blood lipids. Expanded biochemical measurements may include triglycerides and HDL cholesterol.

 

Option D. Behavioral assessment: This involves collecting data on tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, physical activity, and history of raised blood pressure and diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

STEPwise approach:

choices.text: Alveoli filled with neutrophils
Dense fibrosis of the alveolar walls
Enlarged air space
Hyaline membranes and collapsed alveoli

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant born at 7 months of gestation was brought to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress and was pronounced dead shortly after arrival. During the autopsy, which of the following findings would most likely be observed in the lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyaline membranes and collapsed alveoli

 

  • Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, occurs predominantly in premature infants due to insufficient production of surfactant.
  • This deficiency leads to alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and the formation of hyaline membranes, which are proteinaceous deposits lining the alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveoli filled with neutrophils: This finding would be more indicative of an infectious process such as pneumonia rather than NRDS.

 

Option B. Dense fibrosis of the alveolar walls: Fibrosis of the alveolar walls is a characteristic of chronic lung disease and not typical of the acute setting of NRDS.

 

Option C. Enlarged air space: Enlargement of air spaces is associated with emphysematous changes, which are not a feature of NRDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of hyaline membranes and collapsed alveoli on lung autopsy is a hallmark of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, a condition related to surfactant deficiency in premature infants.

 

Pathophysiology of NRDS:

 

  • Caused by deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, which is normally produced by type II pneumocytes.
  • Surfactant reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse.
  • In premature infants (especially < 34 weeks), surfactant deficiency leads to:
    • Alveolar collapse (atelectasis)
    • Hypoxia and acidosis
    • Injury to alveolar-capillary membrane
    • Leakage of proteinaceous material forms hyaline membranes

choices.text: Familial adenomatous polyposis
Gardner syndrome
Juvenile polyposis syndrome
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of episodic abdominal pain and stools with blood and mucus. Physical examination reveals a finding shown in the image. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

 

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome presents with multiple hamartomatous polyps that can lead to obstruction and with hyperpigmentation of the mouth, lips, hands, and/or genitalia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Familial adenomatous polyposis: Familial adenomatous polyposis and its subtypes are not associated with the findings given in the question

 

Option B. Gardner syndrome: Gardner syndrome and Turcot syndrome, are associated with thousands of colonic polyps, though not typically hamartomatous polyps. The diseases are not associated with hyper pigmented lip macules.

 

Option C. Juvenile polyposis syndrome: Hamartomatous polyps can occur in patients with juvenile polyposis syndrome, but hyper pigmented lip macules are not present

 

Educational Objective:
