  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) should be considered in children presenting with GI symptoms (abdominal pain, bloody stools) and characteristic mucocutaneous pigmentation.
  • The presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps on endoscopy further supports this diagnosis.

choices.text: Nephrocalcinosis
Putty kidney
Psoas calcification
Staghorn calculus

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents with persistent abdominal pain and sterile pyuria. An X-ray reveals extensive calcification within the renal parenchyma, presenting as a dense, amorphous mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Putty kidney

 

  • This condition is typically a consequence of renal tuberculosis, leading to chronic infection and extensive calcification of the kidney, turning it into a putty-like mass.
  • The X-ray in the provided image shows extensive, dense calcification characteristic of this condition, not just localized to the pelvis but affecting more extensive areas of the renal parenchyma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrocalcinosis: While it involves calcium deposition within the renal parenchyma, nephrocalcinosis generally presents with more diffuse, granular calcifications, not the dense, confluent calcifications associated with a putty kidney.

 

Option C. Psoas calcification: This would be located within the psoas muscle along the lumbar spine, external to the kidney.

 

Option D. Staghorn calculus: Involves a branching calculus within the renal pelvis and extending into the calyces, distinct from the extensive parenchymal calcification seen with a putty kidney.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Putty kidney results from chronic infection leading to extensive renal calcification, typically from tuberculosis.
  • It presents as a dense, amorphous calcification encompassing much of the kidney, distinguishable on X-rays from other forms of renal calcifications.

choices.text: Hepatic Gluconeogenesis
Dietary Glucose
Hepatic Glycogenolysis
Muscle Glycogenolysis

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual who had dinner at 8 pm records a fasting blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL at 7 am the next morning. What is the most likely source of glucose in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

 

  • After an overnight fasting, the body maintains blood glucose levels through hepatic glycogenolysis.
  • Glycogenolysis is the process by which glycogen stored in the liver is broken down into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream.
  • This mechanism is crucial in the early stages of fasting (such as overnight) to ensure a steady supply of glucose for essential bodily functions.
  • In this scenario, the individual had dinner at 8 pm, and the glucose level was measured at 7 am the next morning.
  • The elevated fasting glucose level of 180 mg/dL indicates that the liver has been breaking down its glycogen stores to release glucose into the bloodstream.
  • The body's shift from dietary glucose to stored glucose occurs within a few hours post-meal, making hepatic glycogenolysis the most likely source of glucose in this timeframe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic Gluconeogenesis: While gluconeogenesis also contributes to blood glucose levels, it becomes more prominent after prolonged fasting (beyond 24 hours). Since the patient fasted overnight, gluconeogenesis would not be the primary source of glucose.

 

Option B. Dietary Glucose: Dietary glucose would not be present in significant amounts in the bloodstream after an 11-hour fast, as it would have been utilized or stored within a few hours post-consumption.

 

Option D. Muscle Glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis does not significantly contribute to blood glucose levels because muscle glycogen is primarily used for local energy production within muscle tissues and lacks the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase needed to release free glucose into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During an overnight fast, Hepatic glycogenolysis is the primary source of glucose to maintain blood glucose levels.

choices.text: HSV-2 (Herpes Simplex Virus type 2)
Molluscum contagiosum
HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus)

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of pain in the genital region. Upon examination, you observe a cluster of small, painful vesicles on the genitalia. The patient also reports enlarged and tender lymph nodes in the groin area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV-2 (Herpes Simplex Virus type 2)

 

  • HSV-2 is the correct diagnosis. Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is characterized by painful, recurrent vesicular lesions in the genital area.
  • The presence of painful vesicles and tender lymphadenopathy in the groin strongly supports a diagnosis of HSV-2, which often presents with these symptoms during primary outbreaks and can recur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This viral infection causes small, pearly, umbilicated lesions that are typically painless, which does not match the patient's presentation of painful vesicles.

 

Option C. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Human Papillomavirus typically causes warts, which are painless and not vesicular. The most common types associated with genital warts are HPV-6 and HPV-11.

 

Option D. HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): While HIV can cause a wide range of symptoms, it does not typically present with painful genital vesicles. HIV symptoms are more systemic and chronic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the clinical presentation of HSV-2 infection, which includes painful vesicular lesions on the genitalia accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy.
  • This presentation helps differentiate HSV-2 from other causes of genital lesions, such as HPV or molluscum contagiosum.

choices.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT
Cervical spine stabilization, IV Cannulation, intubation, CECT
Intubation, IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, CECT

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

 

  • The first step in the management of a trauma patient is ensuring the stability of the cervical spine, especially if there is any suspicion of cervical spine injury, which is common in road traffic accidents (RTA). The steps are as follows:
    1. Cervical spine stabilization: This is critical to prevent any potential spinal cord damage. The cervical spine should be immobilized before any further intervention.
    2. Intubation: Airway management is the next priority. Ensuring the airway is open and secured is vital, and intubation is performed if the patient’s airway is compromised.
    3. IV cannulation: Establishing IV access is important for the administration of fluids and medications.
    4. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): This imaging modality is used for a detailed evaluation of the injuries once the patient is stabilized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT: Intubation before cervical spine stabilization can lead to further spinal cord injury if the cervical spine is unstable.

 

Option C. Cervical spine stabilization, IV Cannulation, intubation, CECT: IV cannulation before intubation is not ideal because airway management takes precedence over IV access.

 

Option D. Intubation, IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, CECT: Both intubation and IV cannulation before cervical spine stabilization can result in potential harm if the cervical spine is not secured first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Always assess and stabilize the cervical spine before performing intubation in trauma patients to prevent spinal cord injury.

choices.text: 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a
1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d
1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d
1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

questions.text: Match the following radiological views with sinuses seen:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

choices.text: TORCH infections
Syphilis
Gestational diabetes mellitus
Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: A 31-year-old G4A3 woman presents with a history of recurrent pregnancy losses: one miscarriage at 8 weeks, a second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and a third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks due to preterm delivery associated with early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thromboembolic events, and other complications.
  • The history of multiple early miscarriages, as well as a later pregnancy loss associated with early-onset preeclampsia, strongly suggests APS.
  • APS is known to cause placental insufficiency, leading to pregnancy complications such as preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction, and recurrent miscarriages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other infections, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex) can cause congenital infections and pregnancy complications but are less likely to explain recurrent pregnancy losses and early-onset preeclampsia in this context.

 

Option B. Syphilis: While syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including stillbirth and congenital infection, it is not typically associated with the specific pattern of recurrent early miscarriages and preeclampsia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes is a condition that develops during pregnancy and is characterized by high blood sugar levels. It can lead to complications such as macrosomia and preterm birth but is not typically associated with recurrent early pregnancy losses or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is strongly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss and pregnancy complications such as early-onset preeclampsia.
  • This autoimmune disorder should be considered in patients with a history of multiple miscarriages and severe pregnancy-related complications.

choices.text: IL4
IL6
IL10
TGF Beta

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic liver disease is being evaluated for increased fibrosis. Which of the following cytokines is most associated with promoting fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF Beta

 

  • The correct answer is TGF Beta (Transforming Growth Factor Beta). TGF Beta is widely recognized as one of the most potent fibrogenic cytokines.
  • It plays a crucial role in the process of fibrosis by promoting the differentiation of fibroblasts into myofibroblasts, which are cells that produce a large amount of the extracellular matrix, particularly collagen.
  • This action is central to the pathology of fibrotic diseases, including liver fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and renal fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL4: IL4 does have a role in fibrosis but primarily through its ability to promote the differentiation of Th2 cells, which can indirectly influence fibrotic processes. However, it is not considered the most potent fibrogenic cytokine compared to TGF Beta.

 

Option B. IL6: While IL6 is involved in inflammation and can have fibrogenic effects, its direct role in fibrosis is not as significant as TGF Beta's. IL6 primarily acts by promoting inflammation, which can secondarily lead to fibrosis.

 

Option C. IL10: IL10 is primarily an anti-inflammatory cytokine and actually works to reduce inflammation and suppress fibrogenic pathways, making it the least likely to be a potent promoter of fibrosis among the options listed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TGF Beta is the most fibrogenic cytokine among those listed, playing a central role in the induction of fibrosis across various tissues by stimulating myofibroblast differentiation and collagen production.

choices.text: Isospora
Cryptosporidium
Cyclospora
Microspora

questions.text: During a laboratory session, a microbiology technician is examining a stool sample under the microscope after performing Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining. The sample reveals oocysts that measure 8-10 µm in diameter. These oocysts show variable acid-fast properties and are from a patient who presented with prolonged watery diarrhea after traveling to a tropical region. Based on these findings, which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cyclospora

 

  •  Cyclospora cayetanensis, a coccidian parasite, produces oocysts that are about 8-10 µm in diameter and demonstrate variable acid-fast staining properties, which can be detected using Ziehl-Neelsen staining.
  • This organism typically causes cyclosporiasis, a gastrointestinal illness characterized by watery diarrhoea, which is common in tropical and subtropical regions.
  • The oocysts of Cyclospora exhibit blue-green autofluorescence under ultraviolet light, aiding in its identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isospora: This parasite also causes gastrointestinal symptoms but its oocysts are larger (about 20-30 µm) and exhibit a different staining pattern.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium: Although Cryptosporidium oocysts are acid-fast, they are smaller (4-6 µm in diameter) compared to those of Cyclospora.

 

Option D. Microspora: This refers to a group of fungi, which are not typically identified using Ziehl-Neelsen staining and do not produce oocysts but rather spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Cyclospora cayetanensis as the causative agent in cases of travelers' diarrhoea with visible oocysts in stool samples stained by Ziehl-Neelsen, noting the specific size and variable staining properties characteristic of this organism.

choices.text: Entactin
Heparan sulfate
Fibronectin
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: Which protein in the glomerular basement membrane is primarily responsible for charge-dependent filtration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heparan sulfate

 

  • Heparan sulfate is a key proteoglycan in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) that plays a crucial role in charge-dependent filtration.
  • The negatively charged heparan sulfate helps repel negatively charged molecules, such as albumin, preventing them from passing through the filtration barrier.
  • This charge-selective property is essential for the normal functioning of the glomerular filtration barrier, ensuring that proteins are retained in the bloodstream while allowing the passage of smaller molecules into the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin is a glycoprotein that plays a role in linking laminin and collagen type IV in the basement membrane, contributing to its structural integrity but not primarily involved in charge-dependent filtration.

 

Option C. Fibronectin: This glycoprotein is involved in cell adhesion and wound healing. It is present in the extracellular matrix and plays roles in cell adhesion, growth, migration, and differentiation, but it is not primarily responsible for the charge-selective properties of the GBM.

 

Option D. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen is crucial for the structural scaffold of the basement membrane, providing support and strength. While essential for the integrity of the GBM, it does not contribute to the charge-dependent filtration process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heparan sulfate in the glomerular basement membrane is essential for charge-dependent filtration, helping to prevent negatively charged proteins from passing into the urine and maintaining the selective permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier.

choices.text: Yellow bag
Red bag
White containers
Blue box

questions.text: A laboratory technician is cleaning up after a blood collection drive and needs to dispose of used vacutainers correctly. Where should vacutainers be disposed of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red bag

 

  • Vacutainers fall into the red category, which is designated for contaminated waste that is recyclable.
  • This includes waste generated from disposable items such as tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes), and vacutainers (with their needles cut) and gloves.
  • These items are typically autoclaved, microwaved, or hydroclaved, followed by shredding and recycling.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Artery forceps
Kocher's forceps
Mixter forceps
Needle holder

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

  • The instrument shown is a Mixter forceps, also known as a right-angle forceps.
  • It is characterized by its right-angle tip and is used to clamp, dissect, and occlude blood vessels and tissues in deep or hard-to-reach areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artery forceps: These are typically straight or curved forceps used to grasp and hold vessels and other tissues to control bleeding. They do not have the distinctive right-angle shape seen in the Mixter forceps.

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: These have a straight or slightly curved serrated tip and are used to grasp tough tissue. They usually have a tooth at the tip, unlike the Mixter forceps.

 

Option D. Needle holder: This instrument is used to hold a suturing needle for closing wounds during surgery. It has a short, sturdy tip and a ratchet handle to securely hold the needle, which is different from the right-angle tip of the Mixter forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mixter forceps are specialized surgical instruments used for clamping, dissection, and occlusion in difficult-to-access areas.
  • Recognizing the distinctive right-angle design helps in identifying its specific use in surgical procedures.

choices.text: I alone is correct
I, III and IV are correct
I, II and III are correct
II, III and IV are correct

questions.text:
A Policy analyst is evaluating different countries' quality of life measures for a global health report. She is focusing on the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) to compare various nations. Which of the following sets of components are considered in the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)? 

 

I. Expectancy of life at birth
II. Expectancy of life at age one
III. Infant mortality rate
IV. Literacy rate
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, III and IV are correct

 

  • The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life or well-being of a country. It considers the following three components:
    • II. Expectancy of life at age one: This reflects the average number of years a person is expected to live after reaching age one.
    • III. Infant mortality rate: This is the number of infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.
    • IV. Literacy rate: This measures the percentage of people aged 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement about their everyday life.

 

Other Option:

 

I. Expectancy of life at birth is a component of the HDI, not PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HDI Vs PQLI

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene.
The CFTR gene is located on chromosome 7q.
Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels are measured for newborn screening.
Sweat chloride test with a concentration >100 mEq/L is considered diagnostic for cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with recurrent respiratory infections, chronic cough, and failure to thrive. The physician suspects cystic fibrosis and orders several diagnostic tests. Which of the following statements is not true regarding cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweat chloride test with a concentration >100 mEq/L is considered diagnostic for cystic fibrosis.

 

  • False. While a sweat chloride concentration >60 mEq/L is considered diagnostic for CF, a concentration >100 mEq/L is not specifically the diagnostic threshold.
  • The standard diagnostic concentration remains >60 mEq/L.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene: True. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7.

 

Option B. The CFTR gene is located on chromosome 7q: True. The CFTR gene is located on chromosome 7q.

 

Option C. Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels are measured for newborn screening: True. Immunoreactive trypsinogen levels are measured for newborn screening as they tend to be elevated in CF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A sweat chloride concentration >60 mEq/L is diagnostic for cystic fibrosis, not >100 mEq/L.

choices.text: E2V2M3
E3V3M3
E2V3M4
E3V2M2

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess a patient's level of consciousness after a head injury.
  • The GCS score is determined by evaluating three components: eye-opening response (E), verbal response (V), and motor response (M). The patient's responses are scored as follows:
    • Eye Opening (E): E2: Opens eyes to painful stimulus.
    • Verbal Response (V): V3: Speaks inappropriate words.
    • Motor Response (M): M4: Withdraws limbs to painful stimulus.

 

Summing these scores: E2 + V3 + M4 = 9.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E2V2M3: This would be incorrect because the verbal response is V2 (incomprehensible sounds) and motor response is M3 (flexion withdrawal), which does not match the patient's responses.

 

Option B. E3V3M3: This would be incorrect because the eye-opening response is E3 (to verbal command), which is not consistent with the patient opening eyes to painful stimulus.

 

Option D. E3V2M2: This would be incorrect because the motor response is M2 (extension to pain), which does not match the patient's withdrawal to painful stimulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a standardized tool for assessing consciousness in patients with head injuries, with scores based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

choices.text: Inhibit extrinsic pathway
Inhibits platelet aggregation
Enhance fibrin degradation
Inhibit clot formation

questions.text: A physician is discussing the emergency treatment of acute ischemic stroke with a group of medical students. The focus is on the administration of a medication that plays a critical role in restoring blood flow. What is the primary mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) used in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

 

  • Tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) converts plasminogen to plasmin that breaks the thrombus, which results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus (thrombolysis).

 

Drugs in this class include:

 

S – Streptokinase

U – Urokinase

R – Reteplase

A – Alteplase

T – Tenecteplase

 

Indication → Pulmonary embolism with
                        hemodynamic instability
                        Acute ischemic stroke
                        Acute MI

Overdose of thrombolytics

→ Leads to bleeding

→ Antidotes: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid
   [EACA] Tranexamic Acid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibit extrinsic pathway: This is not the mechanism of tPA. The extrinsic pathway involves the activation of clotting factors by tissue factor and is more related to clot formation rather than breakdown.

 

Option B. Inhibit platelet aggregation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Platelet aggregation is inhibited by drugs like aspirin and clopidogrel, not by tPA.

 

Option D. Inhibit clot formation: This is not the mechanism of tPA. Inhibition of clot formation is achieved by anticoagulants like heparin and warfarin, whereas tPA is involved in clot breakdown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

choices.text: Topical mupirocin
Oral Vancomycin
Inhaled colistin
IV Vancomycin

questions.text: During a routine screening in a hospital after identifying an MRSA outbreak, a healthcare worker from the neonatal intensive care unit tests positive for MRSA colonization in the anterior nares. To mitigate the risk of spreading the infection to vulnerable newborns, what is the recommended treatment for the healthcare worker to eradicate the nasal colonization of MRSA?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Topical mupirocin

 

  • Anterior nares are the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA.
  • Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Other drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Vancomycin and Option D. IV Vancomycin: Vancomycin is typically used for systemic MRSA infections and is administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. It is not appropriate for eradicating nasal colonization.

 

Option C. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is used for multi-drug-resistant gram-negative infections and is not indicated for MRSA, especially not for nasal colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

choices.text: Sarcoidosis
COPD
Pulmonary fibrosis
Bronchiectasis

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with chronic respiratory symptoms including shortness of breath and a persistent cough. The patient's spirometry results are shown in the graph, with the abnormal curve representing their condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COPD

 

  • The graph shows spirometry results, comparing normal lung function (blue curve) with a diseased state (red curve).
  • The characteristic feature in the diseased curve is a reduced FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in one second) and a decreased FEV1/FVC (forced vital capacity) ratio, which is typical of obstructive lung diseases such as Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).
  • In COPD, there is airflow limitation due to airway obstruction, which makes it difficult to expel air rapidly, hence the reduced FEV1.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: This condition typically presents with a restrictive pattern on spirometry, characterized by a proportional reduction in both FEV1 and FVC, leading to a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio. The graph does not depict this pattern.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis also presents with a restrictive pattern on spirometry, where both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, maintaining a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is not shown in the graph.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: This condition can present with an obstructive pattern similar to COPD, but it is not as common as COPD in producing the specific spirometric pattern shown. COPD is a more likely diagnosis given the typical presentation and spirometry results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic spirometry finding in COPD is a reduced FEV1 and a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, indicative of obstructive airway disease.
  •  This distinguishes it from restrictive lung diseases such as sarcoidosis and pulmonary fibrosis, where the FEV1/FVC ratio is usually normal or increased.

choices.text: Pre-invasive diagnostic test
Continue pregnancy
Chromosome screening
Terminate pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, currently 14 weeks pregnant, reports that she accidentally underwent a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. She is concerned about the potential effects on her baby. What should be the next step advised to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue pregnancy

 

  • The concern about radiation exposure during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, is understandable given the potential risks to the developing fetus.
  • However, the amount of radiation from a single chest X-ray is relatively low, typically around 0.01 millisieverts (mSv).
  • For comparison, the threshold for potential fetal harm is generally considered to be around 100 mSv.
  • At 7 weeks of gestation, the developing fetus is in the embryonic period, and while it is a sensitive period, the dose from a chest X-ray is significantly below the level that would warrant termination of the pregnancy.
  • Therefore, continuing the pregnancy is advised, as the risk to the fetus from this low dose of radiation is minimal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This option is not necessary at this stage. Pre-invasive diagnostic tests, such as amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling (CVS), are typically performed when there is a higher risk of chromosomal abnormalities or other specific indications, not due to low-level radiation exposure from a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is generally recommended if there are specific risk factors for chromosomal abnormalities, such as advanced maternal age or a known genetic condition in the family. The exposure to radiation from a single chest X-ray does not increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities to warrant this screening.

 

Option D. Terminate pregnancy: Terminating the pregnancy is not justified based on the exposure to a single chest X-ray. The level of radiation exposure is well below the threshold that would pose a significant risk to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is very low and does not warrant termination of pregnancy or invasive diagnostic procedures.
  • Continuing the pregnancy is the appropriate advice in this scenario.

choices.text: Tardive dyskinesia; switch to atypical antipsychotic
Akathisia; add beta-blocker
Parkinsonism; add anticholinergic
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome; discontinue antipsychotic

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with chronic schizophrenia has been on haloperidol for the past 6 months. During his follow-up visit, he reports feeling constantly restless and unable to sit still. He describes an intense urge to keep moving his legs. On examination, he is noted to be constantly shifting his weight from one foot to another. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Akathisia; add beta-blocker

 

  • The patient's symptoms of constant restlessness, urge to move, and inability to sit still is characteristic of akathisia, a common side effect of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics like haloperidol.
  • The first-line treatment for akathisia is often a beta-blocker, such as propranolol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia; switch to atypical antipsychotic: Tardive dyskinesia typically involves involuntary, repetitive movements, not an urge to move.

 

Option C. Parkinsonism; add anticholinergic: Parkinsonism would present with rigidity, tremors, and bradykinesia, not an urge to move.

 

Option D. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome; discontinue antipsychotic: It is a severe condition with fever, rigidity, and altered mental status, which are not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, and inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time.
  • They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments.
  • It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. The drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

choices.text: Tzanck cells
Pund cells
Henderson-Patterson bodies
Guarnieri bodies

questions.text: A 24-year-old individual seeks medical attention for the lesion in genital area, as shown in the image. A diagnostic swab of the lesion's base is performed to identify the underlying cause. What microscopic finding is most likely associated with these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tzanck cells

 

  • The clinical picture is suggestive of genital herpes.
  • Tzanck cells – multinucleate giant cells seen on Tzanck smear in herpes simplex virus infection.
  • Herpetic lesions usually begin as clusters of small bumps, then blisters, followed by open sores or ulcers.
  • Lesions coalesce and usually heal over several weeks at various rates.
  • Local pain is a prominent and common complaint.
  • Patients with genital herpes may also complain of pain in the groin area secondary to local adenopathy.
  • Women often present with complaints of genital swelling, discharge, and dysuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pund cells: Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. Seen in granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) which is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Donovanosis lesions usually start as a painless papule or subcutaneous nodule. The lesions develop the classic “beefy-red” appearance due to their high vascularity. The initial lesion takes on an ulcerative morphology after minor trauma. There is usually no regional lymphadenopathy. Developing subcutaneous granulomas known as pseudo buboes is possible.

 

 

Option C. Henderson-Patterson bodies: Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies, or Henderson-Paterson bodies) are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are painless, discrete, nontender, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules (bumps, dimples) that show a central umbilication.

 

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies: B-type inclusions, formerly known as Guarnieri bodies are cellular features found upon microscopic inspection of epithelial cells of individuals suspected of having poxvirus or vaccinia virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of Tzanck cells, which are multinucleated giant cells, is indicative of herpes simplex virus infection.
  • This is the most likely microscopic finding in a patient with painful genital lesions consistent with genital herpes.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with pain and swelling on the lateral aspect of the wrist, specifically in the anatomical snuff box area. Which of the following muscles forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression found on the lateral aspect of the wrist and hand. It is most prominent when the thumb is extended.
  • The lateral boundary (radial border) of the anatomical snuff box is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus muscles.
  • These muscles are responsible for extending and abducting the thumb, respectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: While the extensor pollicis brevis forms part of the lateral boundary, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuff box.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary, and the abductor pollicis brevis is not involved in forming the boundaries of the anatomical snuff box.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis brevis is not part of the anatomical snuff box boundaries; the abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus muscles.

choices.text: Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase
Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase
Phenylalanine hydroxylase

questions.text: A paediatrician notes that a patient's urine has a distinctive burnt sugar smell during a metabolic evaluation. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

  •  This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids such as leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • A deficiency in this enzyme leads to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), which is characterized by the accumulation of these branched-chain amino acids and their corresponding keto acids in the body.
  • This accumulation results in the distinct burnt sugar or maple syrup smell of the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: This enzyme deficiency is related to Tyrosinemia Type I, not typically associated with a burnt sugar smell in the urine but rather with liver and kidney dysfunction.

 

Option C. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency leads to Isovaleric acidemia, where the urine may have a sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid, not a burnt sugar smell.

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency results in Phenylketonuria (PKU), which may cause a mousy or musty body odor, not a burnt sugar smell in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The burnt sugar smell of urine is a hallmark sign of Maple Syrup Urine Disease, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase.
  • This enzyme plays a critical role in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids, and its deficiency leads to significant metabolic disturbances.

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3
A-2, B-1, C-3
A-3, B-1, C-2
A-2, B-3, C-1

questions.text: Match the following types of analyses with their correct descriptions. Which of the following matches the descriptions correctly?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-2, B-1, C-3

 

Option A. Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): 2.The results of a programme are analysed in terms of monetary benefits. This method assesses the economic value of a programme by comparing its costs and benefits in monetary terms.

 

Option B. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): 1.The output of a programme is analysed in terms of results. This method evaluates the effectiveness of a programme by comparing its outcomes to its costs, focusing on the results achieved.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: 3. It is a quantitative method that includes activities and events. This method is used for planning and managing complex projects by identifying and analysing the relationships between different activities and events.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a programme analysed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $
  • CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a programme analysed in terms of Results eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.
  • Input-Output Analysis - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)
  • Network Analysis – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Vertical transmission is possible
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: A global health organization is developing a comprehensive training module for healthcare professionals to improve their understanding of rubella infection and its implications for pregnant women. Which of the following statements is not true about rubella infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

  • Infection with rubella during early pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, is highly dangerous.
  • It can lead to severe outcomes such as miscarriage, stillbirth, and congenital malformations, including congenital heart defects, cataracts, and sensorineural deafness.
  • The severity of the infection is highest in the first trimester, making it the most critical period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of droplet infection: True. Rubella spreads through respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission is possible: True. Rubella can be transmitted from mother to fetus, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

 

Option D. Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness: True. Infection in late pregnancy can cause sensorineural deafness but usually no major abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk of fetal damage in CRS:

 

 

  • Rubella Infection in I trimester: Most disastrous time
  • Infection in early part of II Trimester: Deafness (only)
  • Infection after 16 weeks POG: No major abnormalities

choices.text: Point mutations in the K-ras proto-oncogene
Hypomethylation of DNA
Allelic loss at the site of the APC tumor suppressor gene
Overexpression of the p53 tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: Which of the following is not a molecular change commonly observed in the progression of colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Overexpression of the p53 tumor suppressor gene

 

  • The p53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and its loss of function (not overexpression) is associated with colorectal cancer progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point mutations in the K-ras proto-oncogene: K-ras mutations are a common early event in colorectal cancer, leading to uncontrolled cell growth.

 

Option B. Hypomethylation of DNA: This epigenetic change can activate genes involved in cell proliferation, contributing to tumor development.

 

Option C. Allelic loss at the site of the APC tumor suppressor gene: The APC gene normally helps regulate cell growth, and its loss can lead to uncontrolled proliferation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The progression of colorectal cancer involves a complex interplay of genetic and epigenetic alterations.
  • While the activation of oncogenes (like K-ras) and the inactivation of tumor suppressor genes (like APC) are hallmark events, it's crucial to understand that tumor suppressor genes generally act as brakes on cell growth.
  • Their loss of function, not overexpression, is what fuels cancer progression.

choices.text: Churg-Strauss syndrome
Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP)
Takayasu arteritis
Buerger disease

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents with a four-week history of headaches, fever, and pain in the upper extremities. Imaging studies including arteriography indicate involvement of the thoracic aorta. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Takayasu arteritis

 

  • This condition is a form of large vessel vasculitis that predominantly affects the aorta and its major branches.
  • The symptoms presented by the patient, including headaches, fever, and upper extremity pain, alongside imaging findings showing involvement of the thoracic aorta, align with the typical manifestations of Takayasu arteritis.
  • The disease is more common in females and typically presents in individuals under 50 years old, fitting the patient's profile.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition primarily affects smaller vessels and is associated with asthma and eosinophilia. It does not typically present with thoracic aorta involvement.
 

Option B. Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP): HSP mainly affects children and is characterized by palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement. It is not associated with large vessel vasculitis.
 

Option D. Buerger disease: Primarily associated with heavy smokers, Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) affects small to medium-sized arteries and veins in the limbs and does not involve the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young to middle-aged females presenting with systemic symptoms and imaging evidence of thoracic aorta involvement, as it is a form of large vessel vasculitis predominantly affecting this demographic.

choices.text: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone)
MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone)
TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone)
Insulin

questions.text: Which of the following hormones uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Insulin

 

  • Insulin uses receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling.
  • When insulin binds to its receptor, which is a receptor tyrosine kinase, it induces autophosphorylation of the receptor and subsequent phosphorylation of intracellular substrates.
  • This cascade of events leads to various metabolic effects, including increased glucose uptake by cells, glycogen synthesis, and lipid metabolism.
  • The RTK pathway is crucial for mediating the effects of insulin on glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone): TSH uses the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling pathway, specifically the adenylate cyclase-cAMP pathway, to exert its effects on the thyroid gland, stimulating the production of thyroid hormones.

 

Option B. MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone): MSH also utilizes the G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling pathway, specifically the cAMP pathway, to influence melanocytes and affect pigmentation.

 

Option C. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): TRH acts through G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) that activate phospholipase C, leading to the production of inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG), which increase intracellular calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Insulin uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling to exert its metabolic effects, including glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis.
  • This pathway is distinct from the G-protein coupled receptor pathways used by hormones like TSH, MSH, and TRH.

choices.text: 1.8
10
14
18

questions.text: A nurse is preparing to administer a prescribed dosage of 180 mg from a drug solution that contains 500 mg of the drug per 5 ml. The nurse uses a 2 ml syringe, which is graduated into 10 divisions per ml. How many divisions of the syringe should the nurse draw up to administer the correct dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 18

 

500 mg of the drug is present in 5ml of the solution.

Therefore, 180 mg will be present in (5/500) *180 = 1.8ml

In the syringe provided, 1ml = 10 divisions,

Therefore 1.8ml = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To deliver 180 mg of the drug using the provided 2 ml syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

choices.text: Cystic artery
Cystic duct
Common hepatic duct
Gall bladder

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is undergoing a cholecystectomy, and the surgeon identifies the boundaries of Calot's triangle during the procedure. Which of the following structures is not a boundary of Calot's triangle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gall bladder

 

  • Calot's triangle, also known as the cystohepatic triangle, is an important anatomical landmark during cholecystectomy. It is bounded by the following structures:
    • Cystic duct: The duct that drains bile from the gall bladder into the common bile duct.
    • Common hepatic duct: The duct that carries bile from the liver to the common bile duct.
    • Cystic artery: The artery that supplies blood to the gall bladder.

 

Note: Classically, the inferior edge of the liver is considered one of the boundaries, but for the purposes of identifying the structures related to the triangle, the cystic artery is significant.

 

  • The gall bladder itself is not a boundary of Calot's triangle but rather a related structure that is involved in its proximity.
  • Calot's triangle is bounded by 3C's:
    • Medially - Common hepatic duct
    • Inferiorly - Cystic duct
    • Superior - Cystic artery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic artery: This is part of Calot's triangle as it is often found within the triangle, and identifying it is crucial during a cholecystectomy to prevent bleeding.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This forms one of the sides of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Common hepatic duct: This forms another side of Calot's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calot's triangle is bounded by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the cystic artery.
  • The gall bladder itself is not one of the boundaries of this anatomical triangle.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

  • The caloric test is a diagnostic tool used to assess the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which involves the inner ear and the brainstem.
  • When cold water is irrigated into the ear canal, it causes the endolymph in the semicircular canals to cool down and become denser.
  • This cooling leads to a decreased firing rate of the vestibular nerve on the side of irrigation, which is interpreted by the brain as a head turn to the opposite side.
  • Consequently, the eyes move slowly towards the irrigated side (the slow phase), followed by a fast corrective movement (the fast phase) towards the opposite side, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. (COWS – Cold Opposite Warm Same).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: Incorrect. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side would be expected with warm water irrigation, not cold.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side: Incorrect. Vertical nystagmus is not typically associated with caloric testing, which primarily induces horizontal nystagmus.

 

Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Incorrect. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side is also not a typical response to caloric testing, which primarily affects horizontal eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a caloric test, cold water irrigation in the ear causes horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

choices.text: Strontium ranelate
Ibandronate
Teriparatide
Calcitonin

questions.text: A rheumatologist is discussing treatment options with a 62-year-old female patient who has recently been diagnosed with severe osteoporosis following a minor fall that resulted in a vertebral fracture. The patient expresses her desire for a medication that not only slows the progression of her bone loss but also actively helps rebuild bone. Which medication should the rheumatologist recommend based on its mechanism of promoting both increased bone formation and decreased bone resorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strontium ranelate

 

  • Strontium ranelate is a unique agent used in the treatment of osteoporosis.
  • It has a dual mode of action: it decreases bone resorption and simultaneously increases bone formation.
  • This dual effect is beneficial in managing osteoporosis, as it helps to improve bone density and strength by promoting a balanced bone remodeling process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ibandronate: Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate that primarily acts by reducing bone resorption. It inhibits osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone turnover and increased bone mineral density.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that primarily stimulates bone formation. It acts on osteoblasts, increasing their activity and promoting new bone formation.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity. It is used in the treatment of conditions like osteoporosis and Paget's disease but does not significantly promote bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strontium ranelate is unique among osteoporosis treatments in that it both decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation, making it a valuable option for improving bone health in patients with osteoporosis.
  • Other drugs like ibandronate and calcitonin primarily focus on reducing bone resorption, while teriparatide promotes bone formation.

choices.text: A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4
A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4
A-4, B-2, C-3, D-1

questions.text:
Match the E. coli pathotypes with their respective pathogenesis mechanisms.

 

E. coli Pathotypes:

  1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)
  2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)
  3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)
  4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

     

Mechanisms of Action:

  1. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylate cyclase.
  2. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  3. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  4. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

Explanation:

 

  • A-1: ETEC is correctly matched with "Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylate cyclase." This describes the mechanism by which ETEC causes watery diarrhea, typically seen in traveler’s diarrhea.
  • B-2: EIEC is matched with "Invades intestinal mucosal cells." This pathotype mirrors the pathogenic mechanism of Shigella, involving invasion and inflammation of the colon.
  • C-3: EHEC is known for producing Shiga toxin, which targets endothelial cells, leading to conditions like hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • D-4: EPEC’s primary pathogenic mechanism involves adhering to intestinal mucosa and effacing microvilli, leading to a characteristic attaching and effacing lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Chi-square test
Z test
Unpaired T test
Paired T test

questions.text: A statistician is designing a study to compare the means between a treatment group and a control group. Which of the following is the preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between these two study groups?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unpaired t test

 

  • The Unpaired t test (also known as the independent T test) is used to compare the means between two independent groups, such as a treatment group and a control group.
  • This test determines whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means of the two groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for comparing categorical data, not means.

 

Option B. Z test: This test is used for large sample sizes when the population variance is known. It is not typically used to compare the means between two small or moderate-sized groups.

 

Option D. Paired T test: This test is used to compare means from the same group at different times (matched pairs), not between two independent groups.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Endoderm
Surface ectoderm
Neural crest
Mesoderm

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought with delayed growth. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Examination shows decreased vision in the lateral eye fields of both eyes. MRI shows cystic lesions with areas of calcifications within the suprasellar region. This patient’s lesion is most likely a derivative of which of the following embryological layers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surface ectoderm

 

  • Craniopharyngiomas arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch, a derivative of oral ectoderm, which forms the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Imaging typically reveals a calcified mass within the suprasellar region.
  • This patient, who presents with growth delay, bitemporal hemianopia and imaging showing a suprasellar cystic calcified mass, most likely has a craniopharyngioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost layer of the 3 primary germ layers and gives rise to the epithelial lining of various organs.

 

Option C. Neural crest: The neural crest is derived from the neural plate, which itself is derived from the neuroectoderm.

 

Option D. Mesoderm: The mesoderm is the middle layer of the 3 primary germ layers and its various derivatives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Craniopharyngiomas, tumors with characteristic calcifications in the suprasellar region, arise from remnants of Rathke's pouch, a derivative of the surface ectoderm (not endoderm, neural crest, or mesoderm).

choices.text: Pit method
Dumping method
Trench latrine
Aqua privy

questions.text: An international disaster response team is preparing to set up a temporary shelter for refugees displaced by a recent natural disaster. What type of sanitation facilities should be provided to ensure proper hygiene and prevent the spread of diseases in the camp?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trench latrine

 

  • For temporary sanitation facilities in refugee camps, the most appropriate options include shallow trench latrines, deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines.
  • Among the given choices, the "trench latrine" is the most suitable for providing sanitation facilities to refugees in a temporary camp.
  • Trench latrines are practical, relatively easy to construct, and effective for temporary use in emergency situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pit method: Incorrect because the "pit method" is not specifically recommended as a sanitation facility for refugee camps. While pit latrines are a common option, the term "pit method" is too vague.

 

Option B. Dumping method: Incorrect because the "dumping method" is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps.

 

Option D. Aqua privy: Incorrect because aqua privies, which are similar to septic tanks, are useful at the family level but not recommended for temporary refugee camps due to the complexity and resources required for their construction and maintenance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods of Excreta Disposal in Unsewered Areas

choices.text: Left bronchus
Right bronchus
Trachea
Esophagus

questions.text: Where is the location of the foreign body?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right bronchus

 

  • The X-ray images show a foreign body located in the right bronchus.
  • The right bronchus is more vertical and wider compared to the left bronchus, making it a common site for aspirated foreign bodies.
  • This anatomical difference allows objects to more easily enter and lodge in the right bronchus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left bronchus: The left bronchus is more horizontal and narrower than the right bronchus, which makes it less likely for foreign bodies to lodge there.

 

Option C. Trachea: The foreign body is clearly shown in the bronchial passage on the X-ray, not in the trachea.

 

Option D. Esophagus: The position of the foreign body on the X-ray does not align with the esophagus, which is located posteriorly and not in the bronchial tree.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right bronchus is the most common site for foreign body aspiration due to its anatomical structure, which is more vertical and wider than the left bronchus.

choices.text: Male pseudohermaphroditism
Female pseudohermaphroditism
True hermaphroditism
46, XY intersex

questions.text: A 3-week-old female infant presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with ambiguous genitalia. The parents report that the infant's clitoris appears enlarged, and there is partial fusion of the labia. A karyotype analysis confirms 46, XX. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

 

  • The correct answer is option B, female pseudohermaphroditism.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which is the most common enzyme deficiency in CAH.
  • This condition leads to excess androgen production, resulting in virilization of a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia may resemble a male's.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male pseudohermaphroditism: Incorrect. Male pseudohermaphroditism typically involves a 46, XY karyotype with underdeveloped male genitalia, not relevant to this case.

 

Option C. True hermaphroditism: Incorrect. True hermaphroditism involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue, which is not indicated by the findings in this case.

 

Option D.  46, XY intersex: Incorrect. A 46, XY intersex condition would involve a male karyotype with ambiguous genitalia, not consistent with the karyotype and presentation in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism with ambiguous genitalia in 46, XX individuals due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

choices.text: Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills
CuT200
Danazol
RU486

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of contraception used post-coitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Danazol

 

  • Danazol is not used as a method of contraception post-coitus.
  • Danazol is a synthetic steroid with androgenic properties and is primarily used to treat endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease.
  • It is not indicated or effective as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: These are used as emergency contraception and are known as the Yuzpe regimen. They work by preventing ovulation, fertilization, or implantation if taken within 72 hours after unprotected intercourse.

 

Option B. CuT200: The copper IUD (CuT200) can be used as emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days after unprotected intercourse. It prevents fertilization and may also prevent implantation.

 

Option D. RU486: RU486, also known as mifepristone, can be used for emergency contraception. It works by blocking the hormone progesterone, which is necessary for pregnancy to continue, thus preventing implantation or causing the embryo to detach from the uterine wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Danazol is not used for post-coital contraception.
  • Emergency contraception methods include combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills, copper IUD, and RU486 (mifepristone).

choices.text: <70 per 1 lakh live births
<100 per 1 lakh live births
<50 per 1 lakh live births
<130 per 1 lakh live births

questions.text: A health policy analyst is evaluating the progress towards achieving Sustainable Development Goal 3 (SDG 3), which focuses on ensuring healthy lives and promoting well-being for all ages. Within this framework, what is the specific target for the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) by the year 2030 according to target 3.1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <70 per 1 lakh live births

 

  • Sustainable Development Goal 3 (SDG 3) aims to ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all ages.
  • Specifically, target 3.1 of SDG 3 aims to reduce the global Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births by the year 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

 

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

 

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

 

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

 

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

 

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

 

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

 

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

 

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

choices.text: Mucor
Aspergillus
Candida
Trichosporon

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient, who recently recovered from a severe case of COVID-19 treated with corticosteroids, presents with persistent nasal discharge that has lasted for three weeks. A biopsy from the nasal mucosa was performed, and the histopathological findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

  • The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

choices.text: Acyl carrier protein
LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase)
Cholesterol transporter
Carnitine

questions.text: Which molecule is primarily responsible for the transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carnitine

 

  • Carnitine plays a critical role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • It does this by forming a complex with fatty acids (acyl-carnitine), which facilitates their translocation into the mitochondria where β-oxidation occurs.
  • This process is vital for the conversion of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA, which enters the citric acid cycle to produce energy.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Acyl carrier protein: This protein is involved in fatty acid synthesis in the cytosol, not in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for degradation.
 

Option B. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT is involved in the esterification of cholesterol in the blood, part of lipoprotein metabolism and transport, not related to mitochondrial fatty acid transport.
 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: These proteins (such as ABC transporters) are involved in the movement of cholesterol across cell membranes, unrelated to the mitochondrial transport of fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for β-oxidation, a key step in fatty acid metabolism necessary for energy production.
  • This role of carnitine is crucial in the clinical understanding of metabolic energy processes and associated disorders.

choices.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

 

  • Hutchinson's triad is a classic clinical manifestation commonly seen in late congenital syphilis. It consists of three major features:

 

  1. Interstitial keratitis: This is an inflammation of the cornea that can lead to scarring and visual impairment.
  2. 8th nerve deafness: This refers to sensorineural hearing loss resulting from damage to the eighth cranial nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve).
  3. Hutchinson incisors: These are peg-shaped, notched central incisors, characteristic of congenital syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars: Mulberry molars are another dental anomaly associated with congenital syphilis, but they are not part of Hutchinson's triad. The triad includes Hutchinson incisors, not mulberry molars.

 

Option B. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars: Hutchinson molars are incorrect terminology. The correct term is Hutchinson incisors, which are part of the triad.

 

Option C. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors: Mulberry incisors are not a recognized condition. The characteristic dental finding in Hutchinson's triad is Hutchinson incisors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hutchinson's triad, seen in late congenital syphilis, includes interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors.

choices.text: Affected
Adopted
Aborted
Gender unknown

questions.text: Which symbol traditionally denotes this in pedigree charts?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gender unknown

 

  • The correct answer is D, Gender unknown. In pedigree charts used in genetics research and counseling, different symbols represent different statuses or characteristics of individuals.
  • The diamond shape, as shown in the provided image, is universally used to represent an individual whose gender is unknown.
  • This symbol allows for the inclusion of all individuals in the analysis, regardless of whether their gender has been identified or is relevant to the genetic study.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Affected: This status is typically indicated by shading or coloring in the symbol that corresponds to the individual's gender (circle for female, square for male), not by the shape of the symbol itself.

 

Option B. Adopted: Adoption is often indicated by a dashed border around the individual’s gender-specific symbol (circle for female, square for male), not by a diamond.
 

Option C. Aborted: This status may be shown with a specific notation, such as a triangle, but not with a diamond, which is reserved for unspecified gender.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pedigree charts, a diamond symbol is specifically used to represent individuals whose gender is unknown, allowing geneticists to document and analyze family trees without needing complete information on every individual's sex.
  • This is crucial for comprehensive genetic evaluations where gender may not yet be determined or disclosed.

choices.text: Both drugs are equally effective
Neither of the drugs is effective
Drug A is more effective than Drug B
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the drugs

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is conducting a clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of a new drug (Drug A) and an existing drug (Drug B) for treating a chronic disease. The remission rates observed were 33.2% for Drug A and 32.2% for Drug B. The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug A is more effective than Drug B

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 indicates that the results are statistically significant, meaning there is a less than 5% chance that the observed difference in remission rates occurred due to random variation alone.
  • Even though the difference in remission rates between Drug A (33.2%) and Drug B (32.2%) is small, it is statistically significant, suggesting that Drug A is more effective than Drug B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both drugs are equally effective: This statement is incorrect because the p-value indicates a statistically significant difference.

 

Option B. Neither of the drugs is effective: This statement is incorrect as the study shows remission rates for both drugs, indicating some level of effectiveness.

 

Option D. The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the drugs: This statement is incorrect because the p-value provides sufficient evidence to compare the efficacy of the drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 P-value:

 

  • Is the ‘Probability of Type I error’ (Null hypothesis is true but rejected).
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error.
  • P-value is calculated (on basis of data while Alpha is fixed in advance: by the choice of level of significance employed in the test.
  • P-value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a).
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant.

choices.text: Drusen
Hard exudates
Cotton wool spots
Macular Edema

questions.text: A histopathological examination of the retina from a patient presenting with visual changes as shown in the image provided. The image displays focal, dome-shaped deposits located between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch’s membrane. Based on the structural features observed, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drusen 

 

  • Drusen, also called colloid bodies, are extracellular deposits located at the interface between the Retinal Pigmentary Epithelium and Bruch membrane.
  • Drusen are numerous, minute, whitish, refractile spots with pigmented margins, mainly involving the posterior pole.
  • They are seen in senile macular degeneration and Doyne's honeycomb dystrophy.
  • The material of which they are composed has a broad range of constituents and is thought to be derived from immune-mediated and metabolic processes in the retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • The precise role of drusen in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is unclear.
  • However, drusen are positively associated with the size of lesions and the presence or absence of associated pigmentary abnormalities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hard exudates: Well-defined, bright yellow deposits of extravasated fluid rich in fibrin and proteins. These hyaline or lipid deposits are generally seen as a cluster around a group of leaking microaneurysms. Commonly seen in macular area, in the outer plexiform layer.

 

Option C. Cotton-wool spots: Composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fibre layer.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Accumulation of excess fluid in the extracellular space within the retina in the macular area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drusen are distinct, granular deposits at the interface between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, commonly associated with age-related macular degeneration and can be an early sign of the disease.

choices.text: Epidermoid cyst
Folliculitis
Furuncle
Kerion

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents with a mildly painful, inflamed swelling on his scalp that has persisted for 4 months. He has a pet dog at home. The lesion, is shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kerion

 

  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory response to a fungal infection (tinea capitis) caused by dermatophytes.
  • The condition is characterized by a boggy, inflamed mass on the scalp, often with pustules, hair loss, and sometimes purulent drainage.
  • The presence of a pet dog suggests a possible zoophilic dermatophyte infection. Kerion requires prompt systemic antifungal treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermoid cyst: An epidermoid cyst is a benign lump under the skin caused by trapped keratin and does not present with the severe inflammation and bogginess seen in kerion.

 

Option B. Folliculitis: Folliculitis is inflammation of the hair follicles, presenting as small, red, pus-filled bumps. It is typically not associated with the extensive inflammatory response seen in kerion.

 

Option C. Furuncle: A furuncle, or boil, is a deep bacterial infection of the hair follicle, leading to a painful, pus-filled lump. While it can be similar to kerion, it lacks the characteristic boggy and widespread inflammatory appearance of kerion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory reaction to a dermatophyte infection of the scalp, characterized by a boggy, inflamed area with hair loss. It often requires systemic antifungal treatment and may be associated with pet exposure.

choices.text: Levels 1, 2, and 3
Levels 2, 3 and 4
Levels 2, 3, 4 and 5
Levels 1 to 5

questions.text: Which of these lymph node groups are removed in lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levels 2, 3 and 4

 

  • Lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer typically involves the removal of lymph node groups in levels 2, 3 and 4.
  • These levels are most commonly involved in the spread of oropharyngeal cancer and are therefore targeted during surgical treatment to ensure comprehensive removal of potentially affected nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 1, 2 and 3: This includes nodes in level 1 which are not typically involved in oropharyngeal cancer. Level 1 nodes are more associated with oral cavity cancers.

 

Option C. Levels 2, 3, 4 and 5: This option includes level 5 nodes, which are generally not targeted in lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer as they are less commonly involved.

 

Option D. Levels 1 to 5: This includes all five levels, which is more extensive than typically necessary for lateral neck dissection in oropharyngeal cancer. This is more consistent with modified radical neck dissection (MRND) which includes levels 1 to 5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lateral neck dissection for oropharyngeal cancer involves removing lymph nodes in levels 2, 3 and 4 to manage and prevent the spread of cancer.

choices.text: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
Menetrier's Disease
Gastric Adenocarcinoma
Peptic Ulcer Disease

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with complaints of epigastric pain, nausea, and significant weight loss over the past three months. On physical examination, peripheral edema is noted. Laboratory findings show hypoalbuminemia, and a gastric biopsy finding is shown below. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Menetrier's Disease

 

  • Menetrier's Disease, also known as giant hypertrophic gastritis, is characterized by marked hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa, leading to excessive mucous secretion and protein loss through the stomach.
  • The clinical presentation often includes symptoms such as pain, nausea, and weight loss, along with hypoalbuminemia and peripheral edema due to protein loss.
  • The gastric biopsy findings of foveolar hyperplasia without significant inflammation further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome: This condition is caused by a gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma) that results in excessive gastric acid production, often leading to recurrent and multiple peptic ulcers. The clinical presentation and biopsy findings in the case do not support this diagnosis.
 

Option C. Gastric Adenocarcinoma: While cancer can present with weight loss and epigastric pain, the biopsy findings of foveolar hyperplasia without signs of malignancy are not typical of gastric adenocarcinoma.
 

Option D. Peptic Ulcer Disease: Although peptic ulcer disease could explain the epigastric pain and nausea, it does not typically cause significant protein loss or foveolar hyperplasia, and it usually shows more inflammatory changes on biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Menetrier's Disease should be considered in patients presenting with epigastric pain, significant protein loss, hypoalbuminemia, and gastric biopsy findings of foveolar hyperplasia without significant inflammation.

choices.text: Relative risk
