Attributable risk
Population Attributable risk
Odds Ratio

questions.text: A public health officer is designing an educational program to explain the impacts of smoking on lung cancer incidence. She wants to highlight which variable indicates the difference in lung cancer incidence between smokers and non-smokers. Which of the following variables should she use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attributable risk

 

  • The Attributable Risk (AR) measures the difference in incidence of lung cancer between smokers and non-smokers.
  • It quantifies the proportion of lung cancer cases that can be attributed to smoking. The formula for attributable risk is:

 

Attributable Risk=Incidence of lung cancer in Smokers-Incidence of lung cancer in non-smokers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relative risk: Measures the strength of association between smoking and lung cancer by comparing the risk of lung cancer in smokers to the risk in non-smokers.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk (PAR): Estimates the proportion of lung cancer incidence in the population that is attributable to smoking and represents the incidence reduction if smoking is eliminated. The formula is:

 

 

Option D. Odds Ratio: Measures the odds of smoking among lung cancer cases compared to the odds of smoking among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Attributable risk quantifies the difference in disease incidence between exposed (e.g. smokers) and non-exposed (e.g. non-smokers) groups, indicating the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

choices.text: Montelukast
Sodium cromolyn
Colchicine
Febuxostat

questions.text: A physician is considering various treatment options for a patient with recurrent gout who experiences frequent acute inflammatory attacks. Which medication should the physician prescribe to specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment, thereby reducing the inflammatory response in acute gout attacks?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

  • Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever.
  • One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation.
  • It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment by disrupting microtubules, thus affecting neutrophil mobility and reducing inflammation.
  • This mechanism makes it effective in treating conditions like gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

choices.text: Renal cell carcinoma
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
Congenital PUJ obstruction
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and a palpable flank lump, and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) typically presents in adults between the ages of 30 and 50 years.
  • It is characterized by the development of multiple cysts in both kidneys, leading to bilateral renal enlargement.
  • The patient’s history of hypertension and the presence of a palpable flank lump are consistent with this diagnosis.
  • The ultrasound image shows multiple cysts in the kidneys, which is a hallmark of ADPKD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: This condition usually presents with a single mass rather than multiple cysts. It is also less commonly associated with bilateral flank lumps.

 

Option C. Congenital PUJ obstruction: This typically presents in children with a history of urinary tract infections and hydronephrosis rather than multiple cysts.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease: This condition presents in infancy or early childhood with renal and hepatic involvement. The ultrasound features and the age of the patient do not match this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is characterized by bilateral renal cysts, hypertension, and is most commonly diagnosed in adults aged 30-50 years.

choices.text: Suppurative lymphadenitis
Metastatic carcinoma
Tuberculous lymphadenitis
Kikuchi's disease

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with painless swelling of the posterior cervical lymph nodes. She has no history of tuberculosis or HIV infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculous lymphadenitis

 

  • The presentation of painless swelling of posterior cervical lymph nodes, particularly in a young woman, is highly suggestive of tuberculous lymphadenitis (scrofula).
  • While other diagnoses are possible, this presentation is the most classic for TB lymphadenitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppurative lymphadenitis: This usually presents with painful, tender lymph nodes and systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever). The patient in the case has painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Metastatic carcinoma: Metastatic carcinoma is a possibility, but it's less likely in a young patient with no other symptoms or risk factors. Additionally, tuberculous lymphadenitis is more common than metastatic cancer in this presentation.

 

Option D. Kikuchi's disease: Kikuchi's disease (necrotizing histiocytic lymphadenitis) is a rare condition that primarily affects young women and can present with cervical lymphadenopathy. However, it is often associated with fever and other systemic symptoms, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculous lymphadenitis (scrofula) is the most common cause of painless, isolated posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in young individuals.
  • While other diagnoses should be considered, a thorough evaluation for tuberculosis is crucial, including a detailed history, physical examination, and appropriate diagnostic tests like fine-needle aspiration biopsy with culture.

choices.text: Timolol
Brimonidine
Latanoprost
Dorzolamide

questions.text: A pediatric ophthalmologist is cautious when prescribing ocular medications for infants due to the risk of systemic side effects. One medication known to cause significant side effects, including ocular hypotension and apnea, should be avoided in infants. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause these symptoms in this population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

  • Brimonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used primarily to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma, can cause systemic side effects such as hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia, and even apnea, particularly in infants and young children.
  • Due to these potential risks, it is generally contraindicated in children under the age of 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: While this beta-blocker also decreases intraocular pressure and can have systemic cardiovascular and respiratory effects, it does not commonly cause apnea in infants.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: A prostaglandin analogue used to reduce intraocular pressure by increasing aqueous humor outflow. It is typically well-tolerated and does not commonly cause apnea or significant systemic effects in infants.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: A topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to decrease intraocular pressure; it has a lower risk of causing systemic effects compared to brimonidine and is generally safer for use in younger populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The contraindications and potential systemic side effects of ocular medications in infants, particularly the risks associated with brimonidine, which can include ocular hypotension and life-threatening apnea in this vulnerable population.

choices.text: Posterior
Median
Anterior
Lateral

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is being evaluated for urinary symptoms, and an anatomical assessment of the prostate gland is conducted. Which lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Median

 

  • The median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra.
  • It protrudes into the bladder and forms a structure known as the uvula vesicae.
  • This prominence can be more noticeable in conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), where the median lobe enlarges and can obstruct the bladder neck, leading to urinary symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior: The posterior lobe of the prostate is located behind the urethra and ejaculatory ducts. It is palpable during a digital rectal examination and is a common site for prostate cancer but does not form the uvula vesicae.

 

Option C. Anterior: The anterior lobe, or isthmus, lies in front of the urethra and does not contribute to the formation of the uvula vesicae. It mainly consists of fibromuscular tissue.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes of the prostate are located on either side of the urethra and comprise the bulk of the gland. They do not form the uvula vesicae but can enlarge and contribute to urinary obstruction in conditions like BPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae, a structure that can protrude into the bladder and cause urinary symptoms when enlarged, such as in benign prostatic hyperplasia.

choices.text: Fornix
Pineal gland
Pituitary gland
Falx cerebri

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient is being evaluated for a neuroendocrine disorder. Identify the structure marked in the provided brain image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fornix

 

  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus.
  • In the provided sagittal section of the brain, the marked structure is located near the midline, arching over the thalamus, which corresponds to the location of the fornix.
  • The fornix is involved in the limbic system, playing a role in memory formation and recall.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pineal gland: The pineal gland is a small endocrine gland located near the center of the brain, between the two hemispheres, in a groove where the two halves of the thalamus join. It is responsible for the production of melatonin. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Option C. Pituitary gland: The pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, below the hypothalamus. It is an endocrine organ responsible for hormone secretion. The marked structure in the image is not in the position typically associated with the pituitary gland.

 

Option D. Falx cerebri: The falx cerebri is a sickle-shaped fold of dura mater that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure between the cerebral hemispheres. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The fornix is a major output tract of the hippocampus and is involved in memory formation and recall.
  • It is located near the midline, arching over the thalamus, which matches the marked structure in the provided brain image.

choices.text: Goldmann, Zeiss
Richardson, Koeppe
Koeppe
Goldmann, Richardson, Zeiss

questions.text: An ophthalmologist is selecting a gonioscope for a procedure to examine a patient's anterior chamber angle for signs of glaucoma. Which of the following gonioscopes should the ophthalmologist choose as they are classified as indirect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Goldmann, Zeiss

 

  • Both Goldmann and Zeiss gonioscopes are indirect gonioscopes.
  • They utilize mirrors or prisms to view the anterior chamber angle.
  • This design facilitates the use of the slit lamps illumination and magnification to effectively assess the chamber angle, particularly useful in detailed evaluations required in glaucoma management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Richardson, Koeppe: Incorrect, as both Richardson and Koeppe are examples of direct gonioscopes, which do not use mirrors or prisms but provide a direct view using a convex lens.

 

Option C. Koeppe: Incorrect because Koeppe is a direct gonioscope, not indirect.

 

Option D. Goldmann, Richardson, Zeiss: Incorrect because it incorrectly includes Richardson, which is a direct gonioscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examples

choices.text: Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the upper airway obstruction
It allows for the suction of secretions
Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
Increases dead space and airway resistance

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about tracheostomy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increases dead space and airway resistance

 

  • A tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that creates an opening in the neck to place a tube into a person's trachea.
  • This procedure helps manage airway obstructions and improve breathing.
  • Incorrect. A tracheostomy does not increase dead space and airway resistance; rather, it reduces these factors, thereby improving ventilation efficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the upper airway obstruction: True. A tracheostomy provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing any upper airway obstructions.

 

Option B. It allows for the suction of secretions: True. It allows for the suction of secretions, which is crucial in patients with an impaired cough reflex.

 

Option C. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood: True. A tracheostomy uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A tracheostomy improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space and airway resistance, providing a more efficient breathing pathway.

choices.text: 5HT4 agonist
Dopamine antagonist
Macrolides
Diphenylmethane

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is reviewing different classes of medications for their prokinetic properties to treat a patient with gastroparesis. Which of the following drug classes does NOT exhibit prokinetic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diphenylmethane

 

  • Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug.
  • It is a type of organic compound that is not used for the treatment of gastrointestinal motility disorders.
  • A prokinetic drug is a medication that increases gastrointestinal motility and promotes the movement of food through the digestive system.
  • 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides are all types of prokinetic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5HT4 agonist: 5HT4 agonists stimulate the release of serotonin in the gut, which enhances gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option B. Dopamine antagonist: Dopamine antagonists block the action of dopamine in the gut, which can increase gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option C. Macrolides: Macrolides have antimicrobial properties and also act as motilin receptor agonists, which promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic drug and is not used to treat gastrointestinal motility disorders. Prokinetic drugs include 5HT4 agonists, dopamine antagonists, and macrolides, which all act to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

choices.text: Inferior wall myocardial infarction (RCA)
Lateral wall myocardial infarction (LCX)
Anteroseptal myocardial infarction (LAD)
Posterior wall myocardial infarction (PDA)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain radiating to his left arm and jaw. The pain began about 30 minutes ago and is described as a crushing pressure. He is diaphoretic and short of breath. Which of the following is the most likely infarct location based on the clinical presentation and ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anteroseptal myocardial infarction (LAD)

 

  • The patient's symptoms of chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw are classic for acute coronary syndrome.
  • The ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V4 specifically localizes the infarct to the anteroseptal region of the heart, which is supplied by the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior wall myocardial infarction (RCA): An inferior wall myocardial infarction (MI) would typically show ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, as the right coronary artery (RCA) supplies this region.

 

Option B. Lateral wall myocardial infarction (LCX): A lateral wall MI would typically show ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6, as the left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies this region.

 

Option D. Posterior wall myocardial infarction (PDA): A posterior MI is often indicated by ST-segment depression in V1-V3, as these leads are reciprocally affected by a posterior wall injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 12-lead ECG is a powerful tool for identifying the location of a myocardial infarction.
  • Recognizing patterns of ST-segment elevation and depression in specific leads can guide clinicians toward the likely culprit artery and expedite appropriate treatment decisions.

choices.text: C-ANCA
Anti-topoisomerase antibodies
Anti-mitochondrial antibodies
Anti-histone antibodies

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman c/o chest pain as intermittent and burning. Examination shows tightness of the skin of the fingers; there are small nonhealing, non-purulent ulcers over thickened skin on the fingertips. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium. Which of the following findings is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-topoisomerase antibodies

 

  • Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies (anti-Scl-70) can be found in approx. 40% of individuals with diffuse SSc and indicate a poor prognosis and higher risk of severe interstitial lung disease.
  • Further laboratory findings associated with diffuse SSc include antinuclear antibodies (approx. 90% of cases) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C-ANCA: C-ANCA are positive in approx. 90% of patients with granulomatosis with polyangitis.

 

Option C. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies have a very high sensitivity and specificity for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). This patient does not present with symptoms of PBC.

 

Option D. Anti-histone antibodies: Anti-histone antibodies are characteristic for drug-induced lupus erythematosus and present in approx. 95% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of anti-topoisomerase I antibodies in a patient with skin changes, pulmonary symptoms, and gastrointestinal complaints strongly suggests a diagnosis of diffuse systemic sclerosis.
  • This antibody is not only a diagnostic marker but also a predictor of more severe disease and lung involvement.

choices.text: Chlorothiazide
Chlorthalidone
Metolazone
Hydrochlorothiazide

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 29-year-old man with known hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m²) presents with signs of fluid overload. After initial stabilization, the attending physician evaluates diuretic options to manage his condition effectively given his renal impairment. Which diuretic would be most appropriate for this patient to achieve optimal fluid management without further compromising kidney function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metolazone

 

  • In the context of a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 30 mL/min, the choice of diuretic is important, as not all diuretics are effective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function.
  • Among the thiazides, metolazone remains effective in presence of severe renal failure whereas traditional thiazides like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthiazide are ineffective.
  • The reason Metolazone remains effective in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), where traditional thiazide diuretics are less effective, lies in their pharmacokinetic properties and the way they interact with kidney function.

 

Site of Action and Kidney Function:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney. They inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, and consequently, water.
  • In advanced CKD, particularly when the eGFR (estimated glomerular filtration rate) falls below 30 mL/min, the kidney function is significantly impaired. Traditional thiazides become less effective because they depend on adequate kidney function to reach their site of action and to exert their diuretic effect.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Metolazone:

 

  • Metolazone is classified as a thiazide-like diuretic. Unlike traditional thiazides, it retains its effectiveness even in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • This is because metolazone has additional actions on the proximal tubule of the kidney, where it inhibits sodium reabsorption. This proximal action is not as dependent on kidney function as the action in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: This traditional thiazide diuretic is ineffective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function (eGFR <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Another traditional thiazide diuretic that is not effective in advanced CKD due to its reliance on adequate kidney function to exert its diuretic effect.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Like other traditional thiazides, hydrochlorothiazide is ineffective in patients with severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function.
  • This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

choices.text: Increased intracranial pressure
Heavy meals
Excessive venous pooling at the feet
IVC compression

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of feeling light-headed and dizzy when lying on her back, which is relieved when she lies on her side or walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IVC compression

 

  • The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior venacava (IVC) compression.
  • This condition, also known as supine hypotensive syndrome, occurs in late pregnancy when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart and decreasing cardiac output.
  • This can lead to hypotension and symptoms of dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Changing positions to lie on the side alleviates the compression of the IVC and improves blood return to the heart, thereby relieving the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: Increased intracranial pressure would not typically be position-dependent and would present with other symptoms such as headache, visual disturbances, and vomiting.

 

Option B. Heavy meals: Heavy meals can cause discomfort, but they do not typically cause position-dependent light-headedness or dizziness.

 

Option C. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: While venous pooling can cause dizziness, it is usually related to standing for long periods and not specifically associated with lying on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supine hypotensive syndrome, caused by IVC compression, leads to symptoms of dizziness and light-headedness when a pregnant woman lies on her back.
  •  These symptoms are relieved when she lies on her side, which alleviates the pressure on the IVC and improves venous return.
